Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60G4-6RT1-DXH2-612D-00000-00Victoria's Secret Parent Company To Cut 850 jobs; McDonald's To Shut Down 200 Of Its U.S. Stores; Patrick Mahomes Joins Royals Ownership Team; Democrats Spar With Attorney General Barr On Capitol Hill Yesterday; Grim New Milestones To Report In The COVID-19 Pandemic; Lawmakers Are Negotiating A New Round Of Coronavirus Aid.2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:01ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTPhilip Wegman, Scott Martin, Bryce Doty, Rep. Lance Gooden, Matthew Whitaker, Kurt KnutssonNEWSFinancial072901cb.231Victoria's Secret Parent Company To Cut 850 jobs; McDonald's To Shut Down 200 Of Its U.S. Stores; Patrick Mahomes Joins Royals Ownership Team; Democrats Spar With Attorney General Barr On Capitol Hill Yesterday; Grim New Milestones To Report In The COVID-19 Pandemic; Lawmakers Are Negotiating A New Round Of Coronavirus Aid.Lou Dobbs, Maria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Scott Martin

LOU DOBBS, LOU DOBBS TONIGHT HOST: Join us each day to find out. Be sure to join us. A reminder to preorder The Trump Century. Good night from Sussex.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, July 29. Your top stories right now, 6 a.m. on the button on the east coast. It's a big day in Washington. Big tech on the Hill. The CEOs of Facebook, Amazon, Google, and Apple all appearing for an antitrust hearing today. What's at stake for these industry giants? How does it affect you?

Plus the battle over stimulus is on. We look at the difference between the Republican and the Democratic plans and how they impact your wallet coming up. It is Fed day. Investors listening closely to what Federal Reserve Chairman, Jay Powell, will say today about the economic impact of coronavirus after the central bank announced it is extending its emergency lending program. Two-day meeting coming to a close today.

And a fiery hearing on Capitol Hill between William Barr and the Democrats. The hearing appeared to have more questions than answers at least that were allowed, but as he was grilled the A.G. had a question of his own. How long will we let our cities burn? Meanwhile, federal agents pulling out of Seattle now. Other cities could follow despite ongoing violence. Former New York City Mayor, Rudy Giuliani, with us this morning, 7:30 a.m. Eastern with more on the unrest in America and battling rising crime.

It's another big day for earnings this morning. Dow component Boeing reporting this morning along with General Electric, Anthem, and General Motors. It's all here right coming up. Markets this morning, meanwhile, look like this. Take a look at futures. Fractional moves this morning as the stimulus uncertainty and the economic hit companies are taking due to the coronavirus fuel losses on Wall Street yesterday. Dow Industrials this morning up 24, the Nasdaq up 54, and the S&P 500 up seven.

Plus stores using facial recognition, what you need to know about information being gathered from your image and how it's being used. Mornings with Maria is live right now.

Global markets this morning are mixed. Take a look a the European indices with the FT 100 up about 20 points, the CAC quarante up 31, the DAX Index is lower by 15 points in Germany. In Asia overnight, markets were mostly higher. Take a look. Coronavirus cases are rising in Hong Kong. Hong Kong leader, Carrie Lam, warning the city is on the verge of a large scale community outbreak and the hospital system could face collapse. The Heng Seng Index was off by half a percent overnight. The Shanghai Composite in China up better than 2 percent.

Meanwhile, gold still shining, working its way toward $2,000. Take a look at where we stand this morning, up another $8.70 on the price of gold. Some of the top stories that we are watching this morning, the battle between the next coronavirus stimulus relief plan is heating up. Democrats say that the Republican plan does not go far enough. The two sides are negotiating. The GOP proposing a second round of $1,200 checks for Americans making less than $75,000. Also in the $1 trillion plan from the GOP, cutting the federal unemployment bonus from $600 to $200 a week. Democrats are looking for those payments to go up to $6,000 per household and keeping the $600 a week employment extension in tact. The plan needs bipartisan support in order to pass in the Senate.

Sparks flying on Capitol Hill yesterday as the Democrats spar with Attorney General Bill Barr during a heated House hearing. Democrats grilled Barr on a long list of topics yesterday including his handling of civil unrest in Portland. Barr fired back accusing Democrats of turning a blind eye to ongoing violence across the country.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

WILLIAM BARR, UNITED STATES ATTORNEY GENERAL: Federal courts are under attack. Since when is it OK to try to burn down a federal court? If someone went down the street to the Prettyman court here, that beautiful courthouse we have right at the bottom of the hill, and started breaking windows and firing industrial-grade fireworks in to start a fire, throw kerosene balloons in and start fires in the court, is that OK? Is that OK now?

(END VIDEOCLIP)

BARTIROMO: Barr also denying accusation that he is carrying out President Trump's political wishes. We have more coming up on that. The Trump administration, meanwhile, will no longer accept new DACA applications while it conducts a legal review of the policy. The Obama-era program shielding illegal immigrants brought to the United States as children from deportation. The White House will also renew existing protections for only one year instead of two. The Supreme Court recently shut down efforts to end that program.

Grim new milestones to report in the COVID-19 pandemic. Six states have reported one-day records for deaths yesterday as Texas becomes the fourth state to pass the 400,000 COVID case mark. Dr. Anthony Fauci is now warning parts of the Midwest that there are early signs the coronavirus outbreak could be brewing in Indiana, Ohio, Tennessee, and Kentucky.

Big tech on the hot seat today on Capitol Hill. The CEOs from Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google will testify by video before the House Judiciary Antitrust Subcommittee. They're expected to be grilled over their growing influence and the impact on competition. The testimony could help build public pressure for government action. In separate statements, Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg, and Sundar Pichai all emphasized competition their companies face as well as their contributions to the U.S. economy. Take a look at big tech stocks this morning in the premarket ahead of the big show this morning. As you can see they're higher across the board.

Another big day for earnings, meanwhile. Futures are searching for direction this morning as we await a number of big names. Investors are waiting on Boeing, General Electric, General Motors, General Dynamics, and others all expected to report second quarter results before the opening bell this morning. We'll have all of those numbers when they hit the tape.

Joining me right now is Sit Fixed Income Senior Vice President, portfolio manager, Bryce Doty. Also joining the conversation this morning Fox Business's Dagen McDowell, Real Clear Politics White House Reporter, Philip Wegman, and Kingsview Asset Management Chief Investment Officer, Fox News Contributor, Scott Martin. Great to see everybody this morning. Thank you so much for being here.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great to be here (ph).

PHILIP WEGMAN, REAL CLEAR POLITICS WHITE HOUSE REPORTER: Thanks.

SCOTT MARTIN, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: Hi, guys.

BRYCE DOTY, SIT FIXED INCOME SENIOR VP & PORTFOLIO MANAGER: Morning.

BARTIROMO: And Bryce, let me kick it off with you. We are expecting to hear from the Federal Reserve today after a two-day meeting. What are your expectations from the Fed? We know that rates are expected to stay at these levels until 2024 I believe.

DOTY: Yes, when Fed Chair Jerome Powell speaks to his press conference today, he's probably going to be pretty depressing when he talks about the economy and the justification of that poor state of the economy for why they're extending all these lending programs, and we don't think investors are going to like it. We think investors will essentially howl and Powell today, and it could be a dip. I mean, I get it. He's facing, you know, the harsh, cold facts that, you know, things are really bad. He knows that schools are going to be reconvening soon. He's looking out one or two quarters. There's probably going to be another spike in coronavirus cases before a vaccine comes out, but we're firmly in the - by the dip the vaccine trades, so we have a little powder dry. We're looking to take advantage of this, what I refer to as the howl and Powell trade today, and we'll see how that plays out, but that's kind of how we think the market's going to react to his comments this afternoon.

BARTIROMO: And, of course, the Fed already announcing it is extending the emergency lending program through December, that emergency funds were set to expire in September. So the stimulus keeps on coming. Does that affect what you're doing, Bryce?

DOTY: It does. So on one hand you have this bolstering of the economy, and it certainly is definitely helping corporations feel to (ph) borrow money at extremely low rates. That's been fantastic. I mean, they're doing everything they can, and his message will be that they will continue to do everything they can, every - whatever it takes to get us over the hump, to get companies the liquidity they need to survive to next year. In doing so, you know, he tends to just -

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes.

DOTY: -- talk about all the really bad things going on with the economy and employment and things as well, but we - you know, when you look out past six months, though, there could be an incredibly strong rebound in the economy, and there's a lot of pent up demand out there. People can't - are itching to get out and spend money again. As soon as they feel safe at all, you know, you're going to see a big pop.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

DOTY: The treatments have been better. The fatality rate's coming down, so there's a lot of positive momentum there. We just need to get past the next three, four months, and I think we're on - we'll be at a better track. So we like all of that, and any time -

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes.

DOTY: -- there's a dip or hit, we're going to take advantage of it.

BARTIROMO: Well you make a good point. Scott Martin, jump in here because Larry Kudlow yesterday told Fox Business that he sees the V-shaped economic recovery still in tact despite the coronavirus resurgence. So he was looking, Scott, for 20 percent growth story in the second half is what he told us last time Kudlow joined us.

MARTIN: Yes, that'd be awesome, and it's probably just a delayed V more than anything, right? We probably thought we were going to get into that V just about now, and it looks like it's a couple months off, but something to your point, Bryce, let's just, hey, that things do start to reaccelerate as you just noted in the fall and into the winter. Do you think then the Fed eases off the stimulus kick and we actually see maybe, gosh, a steepening of the yield curve over time here, therefore helping the banks?

DOTY: I do. I agree that, you know, let's say there's is a vaccine that comes out. There's a lot of hope. There's going to be a huge market reaction when that happens, right? You might want to take some money off the table because the next step isn't so good for investors even though it's really good for the economy. So everything's going backwards. You know, whatever's bad for the economy ends up being good for the markets because the Fed is going to just throw a ton of money in there and a lot of stimulus, and then you're right. If the economy gets traction, they're going to pull back, the curve will steepen. That will be good for banks. It might - it wouldn't be good for the longer bonds, and I think that they'll pull back on their purchases of corporate bonds for sure. The lending programs haven't - they haven't done a ton, but that'll probably lessen. So it'll be this balancing act that whenever you see some sort of strength in the economy as an investor you have to think, OK, now the Fed's not going to be quite as aggressive. So it's almost like, you know, a little bit of a contrarian on economic news and definitely the volatility that we're going to see in the markets is just higher - just higher than it was the last few years.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

DOTY: So I - we think that's an opportunity frankly.

BARTIROMO: Yes, interesting. Bryce, it's great to have you this morning. Thanks so much. We, of course, will be watching the developments. Bryce Doty joining us there. We are just getting started this morning. We've got a long coming up. Coming up in the next hour, Oklahoma Senator, James Lankford, is here talking about the latest on the stimulus bill, and mysterious seeds reportedly from China ending up in Americans' mailboxes. And then former New York City Mayor, Rudy Giuliani, is here in the growing unrest in largely Democratic cities. We're going to take a look across the country. In the 8 a.m. hour, Delaware Senator, Chris Coons, joining us to talk stimulus and his new manufacturing legislation. Then Trump 2020 Campaign Press Secretary, Hogan Gidley, talking the latest on the race for the White House coming up. Plus who is watching you? One prominent pharmacy secretly using facial recognition technology for nearly a decade. You don't want to miss it. It's all coming up, but first all that and more. A programming note. Fox Business will be covering today's technology hearing on Capitol Hill. You can watch it starting at noon Eastern this morning, live right here. Plus you've got questions. We've got answers. Our new segment, At the Panel, begins next month. Send in your video questions to maria@foxbusienss.com I want to hear what you're thinking about. You're watching Mornings with Maria live on Fox Business.

Welcome back. Now to the stimulus battle, lawmakers are negotiating a new round of coronavirus aid. One point of contention on both sides of the aisle is funding for non-COVID-19 related items including a new FBI building. President Trump weighed in yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We'll be negotiating. It's sort of semi-year relevant because the Democrats come with their needs and asks and the Republicans go with theirs. So we'll be discussing it with Mitch and all the other people involved. We want to do what's best for the people. I want to do what's best for the people. I want to do what's best for the economy because that means jobs and lots of good things.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is House Financial Services Committee member, Texas Congressman Lance Gooden. Congressman, it's good to see you this morning.

REP. LANCE GOODEN (R), TEXAS CONGRESSMAN: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us.

GOODEN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: What is most important in terms of the getting the economy back up and running and jobs as the president just referred to?

GOODEN: Well, you know, this stimulus package negotiation has so far been a disaster. It started a little too late, and we're now pushing up against deadlines. A lot of things expire at the end of this month, which the end of this month is two days away, and we've got to get the economy going. We can't continue to encourage people to stay home with excessively-high unemployment. That's one of the top sticking points among Republicans in this next package. That $600 number needs to be brought down a bit. I think Democrats privately agree with that because they've not even indicated that that's a red line. I believe they're willing to go down from that $600. There's talk about stimulus payments, another round of the $1,200 checks that we had a few months ago, and we've also got to have liability protections for businesses and schools that are facing lawsuits. Senator McConnell has said that it is a non-starter if we can't get a bill passed that has liability protections. I think we'll get something done in the next week. I'm hearing this could go deep into August, but I don't believe that. I believe by sometime next week we'll have a package that we'll be voting on. It'll probably be bigger than any Republican would like it to be and smaller than any Democrat would like it to be, but I believe it'll get done in the first week of August.

BARTIROMO: So why has it been such a disaster? Is it because things got started late or the Democrats are just pushing back on what our and your colleagues are coming up with?

GOODEN: Well the Democrats were in a good position because about two months ago they just passed a massive bill. They let every far-left member of their caucus get whatever they wanted into that bill. They knew it had no chance of passing. They knew it would go nowhere, but they passed it so then when we came up to this deadline now they could say, see, we've passed something months ago and now we're waiting on you all. And things just unfortunately happened last minute here on Capitol Hill. The negotiations on the Republican side in the Senate started last weekend, but unlike prior packages there is division among Republicans in the Senate. There's not this sense of let's just swallow this bitter pill of this gigantic bill and move forward. We're now in the -

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes.

GOODEN: -- third and fourth round of this, and there is less excitement about growing the deficit by several trillions of dollars, and Republicans, myself included -

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Sure.

GOODEN: -- are prepared for nothing to pass if it's going to be a bad bill.

BARTIROMO: Right. Understood. Philip Wegman, jump in here.

WEGMAN: Congressman, you mentioned the topline items obviously changing. Unemployment insurance, liability reforms, things of that nature. A lot of your Republican colleagues in the Senate seem concerned about the size of the bill and you mentioned that, but do you think that your constituents back home are really concerned about an increase in spending right now? For instance, are they concerned whether or not the funding for a new FBI building is included or do they just want to see something get to the finish line?

GOODEN: I think they want to see something good get to the finish line, but they're absolutely concerned about their grandchildren and their grandchildrens' children paying for large bills that perhaps are larger than they need to be today. Another common concern I get from small business owners across my district is this unemployment number. They say we realize we need to have something, but the $600 figure is so high that we can't get some of our employees to come back to work because they make more money sitting at home, so we need to pass something -

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, that makes total - I mean, yes -

(CROSSTALK)

GOODEN: -- that encourages people to work. And even privately Democrats -

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: And that makes total sense.

GOODEN: -- agree with that. It makes no sense.

BARTIROMO: I'm sure, and when you're talking about $21 trillion in debt, yes, you are going to have to attack this at some point. Now with rates where they are, I can understand some people not seeing the urgency, but at some point you and your colleagues are going to have to come up with a plan to reign in the spending. Let me ask you about the president touting you as energy (ph). He is travelling to Texas today, touring an oil rig in Midland, delivering remarks on America's energy dominance. Congressman, your reaction with oil prices at $41 this morning. What is the situation in terms of our energy potential?

GOODEN: Well, our energy potential is unlimited. The reason it's so low is because demand is low. We're in a crisis obviously, but Texas has been leading the way. The Untied States is in such a great position. The cause of President Trump's willingness to roll back ridiculous - excuse me - regulations from the Obama years and ensure that we don't need to rely on Middle East oil. And we're in a great place in Texas. The president's in Midland today. I know he has a fundraiser later tonight. You know all these oil folks allegedly are hurting, but I understand the president's already raised $5 million for his reelection campaign tonight. People are enthusiastic about his race. I realize that polling today has the president down. The president realizes that, but we're also 100 days out. If there's one thing that everyone, Democrats and Republicans, can agree on it's that anything can happen and no one should be surprised about anything in the final two months of the campaign season.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So do you think Texas is purple or is Texas still a red state, Congressman, going into this election real quick?

GOODEN: I think Texas is still - is still a red state. Obviously the economy's down. People are worried about the future. Our hope is that Democrats pour all of their resources into Texas and make that fatal mistake, ignore the swing states because they think they have them locked down, pour all their money into Texas and let's see what happens. I'm confident President Trump will win big and that we'll be moving forward in a good way.

BARTIROMO: And we'll be watching. Congressman, it's good to see you this morning.

GOODEN: Thank you. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Congressman Lance Gooden. Coming up more than 100 police agencies are backing out of the DNC security contract ahead of this convention because of orders that would prevent them from doing their jobs they say. The fallout right after this.

Welcome back. Backing out, more than 100 police agencies are saying no to a security agreement for next months Democratic National Convention in Milwaukee. At issue a new policy which prevents officers from using crowd control methods like tear gas and pepper spray amid violent protests across the country. One local Wisconsin police chief says this in a statement "We believe in removing those tools the use of chemical irritants or pepper spray from the available resources that the law enforcement officers would have at their disposal if protests become non-peaceful would severely compromise the safety of the public and also the safety of the law enforcement officers who would be assigned to protect the DNC." Dagen McDowell, your reaction.

MCDOWELL: You take away these tools from police officers and you prevent them from doing their jobs, and that is protecting innocent people and preventing violence, and that seems to be something that Democrats, quite frankly, don't understand. So again because every protest, remember, is peaceful. The Portland protests, those are peaceful demonstrators. Seattle, that's peaceful unless peaceful is really a synonym for violence and unrest and looting and arson, but I want to point out (technical difficulty) have stood (technical difficulty). They have - they have defended - there's an editorial in The Wall Street Journal that they've defended disorder, that it - that abominations are fighting crime and enforcing the laws of the land. So what do they expect? I just raise the issue maybe more federal authorities will be required to protect the DNC, and wouldn't that be an irony of all ironies if more federal authorities have to come in to protect any of the Democrats assembling in Wisconsin because this is what they've been pushing back because remember it was the Feds going into Portland that caused the violence. That's like saying that police officers cause people to rob, shoot, and murder folks. It's the world of -

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: That's unbelievable.

MCDOWELL: -- left-wing insanity, left-wing lunacy. That's where we're living.

BARTIROMO: And once again, the media is not calling out the, you know, quote, unquote, "peaceful protests". They're also calling it peaceful, and it is anything but. In fact, we're still waiting on any news out of the Department of Homeland Security to let us know what's going on with those two agents Chad Wolf, the secretary, told me on Sunday two agents may very well lose their eyesight. They're going to lose their eyesight because they were - these lasers were shown in their eyes. So we're waiting to see how they're doing, Philip. Your reaction, Phillip.

WEGMAN: I think what this shows is a complete, stark contrasts between both Republicans and Democrats right now. The situation on the ground in Portland, that was a demarcation between Republicans and Democrats in House Judiciary Committee during a conversation with the attorney general, and now what we're seeing in Milwaukee where you have individual police precincts saying, no, we're not going to put out officers in harms way if you don't give us the tools that we need to keep order.

BARTIROMO: Right.

WEGMAN: And you know, it's going to be incredibly interesting because this is - this is (inaudible) Republican messaging.

BARTIROMO: Yes, let's get to those -

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Conversation with (ph) Bill Barr.

BARTIROMO: -- fireworks on Capitol Hill. Attorney General Bill Barr sparring with Congress -

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: No, I just want to say that was in a conversation with -

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: -- during testimony yesterday. I'm sorry? We're going to take a break. When we come back we're going to give you the highlights and the lowlights of the A.G. Barr testimony yesterday. Wait till you see this. Back in a moment.

MARIA BARTIROMO, ANCHOR, MORNINGS WITH MARIA: Welcome back, good Wednesday morning everybody, thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Wednesday, July 29th. Take a look at markets right here at 6:32 a.m. on the East Coast. We are looking at a fractional move with the Dow Industrials up 20 points, Nasdaq up 50 points right now. Tech on fire once again, S&P 500 up 6.5. It is a big day in Washington this morning.

The big-tech CEOs will testify. Stimulus negotiations go on and there's a Federal Reserve decision as well. All that coming up this morning and futures are trading up ahead of a big day. This after a decline yesterday on Wall Street. Take a look at 4 O'clock on Wall Street yesterday, you had the Dow Industrials down 205 points, the Nasdaq was down 134 and the S&P 500 yesterday gave up 21 points.

Global markets this morning are mixed, European indices right now are looking like this, FTSE 100 up 22, the CAC Quarante in Paris is up 35, but the Dax Index in Germany is lower by 8 points right now. In Asia overnight, markets were mostly higher as you'll see here, best performer overnight with the Shanghai Composite in China, that was up better than 2 percent. The coronavirus pandemic forcing another company to cut jobs, Cheryl Casone with those details right now. Good morning, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS: Good morning, Maria. Yes, L Brands, the parent company of Victoria's Secret says that it is preparing to cut 15 percent of its workforce by about 850 jobs. Most Victoria's Secret stores in the United States are back open after being closed due to the coronavirus. L Brands says it hopes to save $400 million annually through this cost-cutting efforts. There's a stock in the pre-market though, sometimes investors really like to see this, said the stock is up about 18.5 percent in the pre-market.

Well, McDonald's announced on its earnings call yesterday they're going to permanently close 200 of its 14,000 stores in the United States. The company says over half of the low-volume restaurants are inside of Wal-Mart stores. McDonald's says these closures were planned for the coming years, but they decided to speed up the process. Taking a look at Dow component McDonald's in the pre-market stock is barely higher, just a fraction there.

Well, the mystery behind packages of Chinese seeds being sent across the United States may be solved. Police believe that it could be tied to an internet scam called Brushing. That's when companies send packages to you even if you didn't order them. They may post a fake review to boost their ratings and this leads to higher sales. So far 47 states have sent warnings about these seed packages, people are being told do not open or plant those seeds and packages.

And finally, here is a look at what is trending this morning on foxbusiness.com, Pfizer CEO warrants President Trump's executive orders designed to slash drug prices could cause quote, "enormous destruction of the pharmaceutical industry and will cost the United States jobs." TikTok facing possible closure by the U.S. government as Facebook reportedly tries to lure users by offering them money to join its new platform, it's called Reels.

And Patrick Mahomes joins the Kansas City Royals ownership group, becoming one of the youngest team owners in sports, Maria. And those are your headlines from the newsroom, sending it back over to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Cheryl, thank you. There was fiery testimony yesterday, Attorney General Bill Barr clashed with Democrats during his House Judiciary Committee hearing yesterday. AG Barr going toe-to-toe with Democrats on a series of issues from Russia meddling to ongoing protests across the country. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Attorney General, the time is mine.

WILLIAM BARR, ATTORNEY GENERAL, UNITED STATES: You waited to talk to me like this, you didn't need to wait so long.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: When I asked --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Mr. Attorney General, you did answer the question.

BARR: No, you said under penalty of perjury, I'm going to answer the damn question.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You said --

BARR: I'd ask another U.S. attorney to look into the issue of unmasking because of, you know, the high number of unmaskings and some that do not readily appear to have been in the line of normal business.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Clear there. So, I want to be clear, so there's a -- there's another investigation on that issue specifically going on in the Justice Department right now?

BARR: Yes.

JORDAN: Can you give us that U.S. attorney's name, is that something you're comfortable doing?

BARR: John Bash of Texas. Federal courts are under attacks. Since when is it OK to try to burn down a federal court? The U.S. marshals have a duty to stop that and defend the courthouse, and that's what we are doing in Portland. We are at the courthouse defending the courthouse. We're not out looking for trouble.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is former U.S. acting Attorney General Matt Whitaker. And Matt, it is good to see you this morning, what a day yesterday --

MATTHEW WHITAKER, FORMER ACTING ATTORNEY GENERAL: Hi, Maria --

BARTIROMO: They asked him to come testify, but I don't think they really cared about what he was saying. We didn't hear from him, they just kept talking over him. Your reaction?

WHITAKER: Yes, well, this is very similar to my experience over a year ago where I went up in front of the same committee and, you know, it really was a missed opportunity then and a missed opportunity yesterday to solve some of these problems. Violent crime is up in our major cities, and this was a chance for the Judiciary Committee in the house which has oversight of the Justice Department to work with the attorney general to solve some of these problems, to give additional resources, additional tools through legislation and they've completely missed that because they would rather grand-stand and really make up a set of alternative facts that are just not consistent with what we are seeing in some of these cities.

BARTIROMO: Why? Just to go against the president and his attorney general? Why? Why not actually solve problems?

WHITAKER: Yes, I think it is. It's election year, it's hyper partisan and I think to some extent, you know, the narrative -- if you think about the things that the Democrats think they're going to win on, many of them are inconsistent with what the American people want. One of this is the rising violent crime rate, and you saw all of these issues, when Barr was asked, he gave a very simple, straightforward answers as to what the problem was and how to solve it.

And they had no interest in hearing that. And whether it was questions about the Russian collusion fable that they continue to want to perpetuate and suggest that somehow, even though Barr and the Department of Justice recommendation was adopted by a completely independent judge who is no fan of the Department of Justice and the Roger Stone case is somehow that Bill Barr had interfered in that case.

It was just -- it was a complete outrageous example of why Washington is broken, Congress gets nothing done for the American people, and why ultimately, I think the American people need to demand that some of these problems get solved.

BARTIROMO: Dagen, jump in here.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS: I just want to push back on something that Philip said, he used the word conversation, well, about yesterday, that's not what that was. It was a shriek fest. I'll just sit here and say, I'm reclaiming my time, my time. My time! It was the intellectual equivalent what we saw from Democrats yesterday of a petulant child eating toilet paper for attention. That's what the American people got out of that. There was one adult in Washington and it was Bill Barr.

BARTIROMO: Yes, if that point is right --

WHITAKER: Well, Dagen, and you saw I think out of --

BARTIROMO: And you know what? They refused to do -- yes, go ahead.

WHITAKER: No, I was just going to say, I think she's absolutely right. And I think you saw why Bill Barr is the attorney general and why I was happy and proud to shake his hand and hand him the keys to the Department of Justice because he is a serious sober individual that is very smart, that knows the law, that knows the role of the attorney general, and is restoring the rule of law. And he mentioned that several times, and it's true.

And, you know, there's -- this is such an important position, and this is the right person for the right time.

BARTIROMO: Well, they're also trying to muddy the story. In other words, there's a specific situation happening in Portland where they -- the anarchists are trying to destroy federal property, the courthouse. And there is a responsibility to protect that courthouse. That's why federal agents are there. Looking at the unrest across the cities is totally different. In fact, you've got federal agents leaving Seattle, for example, amid growing violence.

The Trump administration is speaking with Portland officials about removing agents from that city as well. If the agents leave Portland, what happens, Matt? I mean, do they recognize what's going to take place? This is not a - -

WHITAKER: Right --

BARTIROMO: Peaceful protest what we're looking at right now, but they refuse to acknowledge it.

WHITAKER: It's not, and we have had dozens of federal law enforcement officers injured, some of them permanently in this attack on the federal courthouse, and somehow, the Democrats yesterday did not seem to care about law enforcement officers being injured nor about the risk of, you know, millions of dollars in property damage happening at a federal courthouse in one of our nation's cities. And so, you know, I just -- again, I think if this is their strategy to win an election this Fall, I just think this is a sad day for America because we should all rally around law enforcement and make sure that we protect our federal assets.

BARTIROMO: Yes, Scott Martin. There are shootings that are up across year- to-date in Chicago. You live in Chicago, what is it like there? I mean, no wonder, the cops are saying, look, we don't -- we're going to pull out of the Democratic National Convention in Milwaukee, you're taking away the tools that we need. What are we doing?

SCOTT MARTIN, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: Yes, if you can hear me. Matt, you know, I'm worried about these cities, though, because if you look at Chicago and where we are dealing with things with respect to how Mayor Lightfoot is handling this. I mean, how far does this go when it comes to federal agents and the fact that they come to the cities and the mayors don't want them in there?

WHITAKER: Well, it's a problem because when I was at the Department of Justice both as chief of staff and as acting attorney general, we spent a lot of time trying to help the city of Chicago and the police force address these violent crime that is plaguing the city. And, you know, we worked together collaboratively on task forces, especially the ATF to, you know, get some of these trigger polar and these illegal guns off the streets.

And if we wanted to send more resources and the mayor and the city council don't want them there, that does a disservice to the citizens who do want to end violence because everyone should be entitled to have their children play in their front yard safely without a risk of a drive-by shooting or a stray bullet killing them.

So, I mean, you know, these mayors and city council members in these big cities need to accept the federal help and let us -- and let the federal government partner with local law enforcement to try to reduce violent crime.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you said it. It's a sad day, Matt, thank you so much. Matt Whitaker joining us --

WHITAKER: Thank you --

BARTIROMO: After that incredible testimony yesterday from Bill Barr. Coming up, who has been watching you? One prominent pharmacy secretly using facial recognition technology for nearly a decade. I'm going to check it out. And then a programming note, Fox Business will be covering today's technology hearing on Capitol Hill. You can watch it all live right here noon time, do join us. You're watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, watching you. Rite Aid secretly using facial recognition systems at hundreds of locations across the country. According to an alarming new investigation by "Reuters", the drugstore chain capturing customers' faces for more than 8 years largely in lower income and non-white neighborhoods, only recently stopping the practice. Joining us right now is the cyber guy Kurt Knutsson. Kurt, good to see you. First of all, where were these cameras and what can the chains do with this information?

KURT KNUTSSON, THE CYBERGUY: Good morning, Maria. You would walk into a Rite Aid store, and mostly Manhattan and Los Angeles locations and predominantly as you said in lower-income areas. And one of these cameras, it's about 6-inches, it's kind of rectangular with the -- what happened is, it would activate their system, look to see if you're one of the suspected shoplifters from previously in a database, and then start notifying store agents that you're now walking into that store.

And then you might walk into the cosmetic area where often the cameras were also positioned and be captured in that location, and similarly, this agent from the store could approach you and say, Maria, we suspect that you were shoplifting at another location, we'd like you to leave the store. Well, that's all fine and well, and you would think that's a great practice for business until it wasn't Maria who was shoplifting a long time ago with somebody else.

It just looks similar to you. And that is somewhat the concern here because technology is right there staring at us. And the other complaint, Maria, is that nobody really -- and very few at the wall -- at the Rite Aid stores had any writings out that indicated the warning to customers that this was going on.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I'll tell you, there's a portfolio of billions and billions of pictures of people, where does this facial recognition data go?

KNUTSSON: That is the big million-dollar question because who owns this data? Who controls the data? Right now, it is a wild west. So hypothetically, the security company that installs it might have had an arrangement or they're now the owner of that data, and do they sell it to someone else? Do they keep it, four or 5 years? That's the real question. What is this information used for down the road? Who is responsible for it and how can we guaranty that we as consumers might have any sort of rights to access that and say, hey, that's not even me and you have my name labeled to that.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's interesting all of this as we continue to scrutinize what China is doing in terms of tracking its citizens, and then at the end of the year, given a social score depending on what they get from that video, and here we are, looking at this kind of practice in America as well. Facial recognition getting --

(CROSSTALK)

There's a big warning, important story.

KNUTSSON: Is that -- yes, but that the concern is also the Chinese might be tapped in to the camera systems that many have manufactured there, some might be in control of that area. So, keep our eye on that one as well.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's a good point because Chinese manufacturers are incredibly prevalent in these manufacturing -- in these companies. So they could have a stake in this and actually have access to that -- to those pictures. Kurt, great point, good to see you, we will continue to watch this important story, Kurt Knutsson joining us there, the CyberGuy.

Coming up, out of this world, Virgin Galactic giving a sneak peak of its tourist space, the plane, it is making a buzz this morning, we're going to check it out when we come right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, time for the Morning Buzz. First up, Emmy likes Netflix. The streaming service topping "HBO" in Emmy nominations for the second time in 3 years with a whopping 160 Emmy nominations. "HBO" is still celebrating its limited series "Watchman", it gained 26 nominations, the most of any program. Dagen, did any of your favorites get a nod?

MCDOWELL: I love "Ozark" and "Succession", they were kind of near the top of the list -- I used this list to figure out what I need to be watching. If you're on Netflix, I encourage people to watch "Monty Pythons", this multi-pod documentary. But the internet seemed most upset about Reese Witherspoon being denied -- oh, Emmy nomination for acting in three shows that also saw other actresses nominated, "The Morning Show", "Big Little Lies" and "Little Fires Everywhere".

But she's also a producer on those shows, so I guess being the boss is more important than just being -- well, a nominated actress.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: I loved the "Big Little Lies". By the way, we're getting into "Yellowstone" which is -- which is great.

MCDOWELL: Is that --

BARTIROMO: And that's a vacation in outer --

MCDOWELL: That is the best, Maria.

BARTIROMO: You love it?

MCDOWELL: Yes!

BARTIROMO: You love "Yellowstone"?

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Me too. It's really good. Vacationing in outer space, Virgin Galactic revealing the cabin of its space plane, the VSS Unity, every white and tail seat will be tailor made, the back wall features a giant silver mirror, so travelers can look at themselves in micro gravity. Scott, are you ready to head to the stars?

MARTIN: I mean, Maria, have you seen this thing? It's basically like a flying dentist office. So, if I need a root canal on the way up, oh, yes! I'll take the flight. Plus, if you think about -- consider what a weird stuff kind of going on in the skies around the U.S. lately. So, it's almost like the aliens are coming for us and they'll probably take us up there anyway. So I think I'll pass on this Virgin spacecraft.

BARTIROMO: All right, finally, the best of friends, the 90s sitcom ranking number one on "HBO Max". The streaming platform was supposed to air cast "Reunion Special" postponed amid the COVID-19 pandemic, Philip, are you surprised that friends still rule?

PHILIP WEGMANN, REALCLEARPOLITICS WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Yes, not surprised at all. What is interesting though is we don't have hard members for viewership. So the old special is bringing us into a new frontier where the only thing that maybe gauges from is subscribers not actually viewers during the moment.

BARTIROMO: Yes, all right, we will take a break, we've got a market this morning fractionally higher, a lot going on in Washington, all right after this break, stay with us.

Many big tech companies told Congress for years that they could self-regulate. Now some of them are asking Congress for regulation ...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WSJ-7TJ1-F03R-N3FD-00000-00Victory! Lawsuit May Proceed Against Facebook's Biometric Surveillance2019-08-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:01ZLexisNexisVictory! Lawsuit May Proceed Against Facebook's Biometric SurveillanceActivist Post

Aug 09, 2019( Activist Post: http://www.activistpost.com Delivered by Newstex) ;   https://www.activistpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/facebook-biometrics-LB.jpgBy Adam Schwartz[1] Biometric surveillance by companies against consumers is a growing menace[2] to our privacy, freedom of expression, and civil rights. Fortunately, a federal appeals court has ruled[3] that a lawsuit against Facebook for its face surveillance may move forward. The decision, by the federal Ninth Circuit about an Illinois privacy law, is the first by an American appellate court to directly identify the unique hazards of face surveillance.

This is an important victory for biometric privacy, access to the courts for ordinary people, and the role of state governments as guardians of our digital liberty.Illinois' Biometric Information Privacy ActThe Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act of 2008 (BIPA[4]) is one of our nation's most important privacy safeguards for ordinary people against corporations that want to harvest and monetize their personal information. BIPA bars a company from collecting, using, or sharing a person's biometric information, absent that person's informed opt-in consent. BIPA also requires a company to destroy a person's biometric information when its purpose for collection is satisfied, or within three years of the company's last contact with the person, whichever is sooner. BIPA provides the strongest enforcement tool: a 'private right of action[5],' meaning a person may file their own lawsuit against a company that violates their privacy rights. The Illinois General Assembly explained, when passing BIPA, that 'biometrics are unlike other unique identifiers' because they are 'biologically unique to the individual.' As a result, 'once compromised, the individual has no recourse, [and] is at heightened risk for identity theft.' Lawmakers also pointed out that the ramifications of biometric technology 'are not fully known.' In Rosenbach v. Six Flags[6] (2019), the Illinois Supreme Court held that BIPA does not require a plaintiff to prove an injury beyond a violation of the statute itself. The court reasoned[7]: When a private entity fails to adhere to the statutory procedures, as defendants are alleged to have done here, the right of the individual to maintain their biometric privacy vanishes into thin air. The precise harm the Illinois legislature sought to prevent is then realized. This is no mere 'technicality.' The injury is real and significant. EFF filed an amicus brief[8] in Rosenbach in support of this outcome, along with the American Civil Liberties Union, ACLU of Illinois, the Center for Democracy and Technology, the Chicago Alliance Against Sexual Exploitation, Illinois Public Interest Research Group, and Lucy Parsons Lab[9].Patel v. FacebookIn 2010, Facebook launched its 'Tag Suggestions[10]' feature. It uses face recognition technology to match known faces in user profile pictures and other photos to unknown faces in newly uploaded photos. If this face surveillance system generates a match, then Facebook will notify the person who uploaded the photo and suggest a 'tag.' If that person accepts the tag, then the person in the photo will be identified by name. Facebook imposed this face surveillance system on users by default. To avoid it, a user must affirmatively opt-out, which most users won't[11] do[12]. Facebook has migrated some of its users from its 'Tag Suggestions' feature to its 'Face Recognition' feature, according to the Federal Trade Commission's recently filed consumer deception complaint[13] against Facebook. The default remains application of face surveillance. In 2015, Illinois residents filed a class action lawsuit in federal court called Patel v. Facebook. The plaintiffs allege that Facebook's 'Tag Suggestions' feature violates BIPA. They reason that this feature collects and uses their biometric information without their informed opt-in consent, and does not satisfy the statutory destruction deadline. Facebook removed the case from Illinois to California, where Facebook has its headquarters. The Patel trial court denied Facebook's motion to dismiss, and certified a class of Facebook users. The appellate court allowed Facebook to take an immediate appeal of the class certification decision.'Standing' and SpokeoThe key issue on appeal in Patel was whether the plaintiffs had sufficiently shown that Facebook's biometric surveillance caused them a concrete injury. The U.S. Constitution limits the federal courts to deciding 'cases and controversies.' That means a plaintiff cannot sue a defendant unless they can show 'standing,' meaning that the defendant has injured them in a concrete manner. You'd think that when a company violates a person's rights under a statute, and that statute provides that person a private right of action to sue that company, then that person automatically has constitutional standing. Unfortunately, you'd be wrong. In Spokeo, Inc. v. Robins[14] (2016), the U.S. Supreme Court held that a person in such circumstances might or might not have standing. This depends, among other things, on the legal history of the particular statutory interest at issue. EFF filed an amicus brief[15] in Spokeo (along with CDT, the Open Technology Institute, and the World Privacy Forum) arguing that standing in such cases should be automatic, but that view did not carry the day. Spokeo can sometimes be a barrier to the enforcement of consumer data privacy laws. For example, when a company's negligent data security practices cause massive breaches of consumers' personal information, the company may argue[16] that the injured consumers cannot sue based solely on violations of data security statutes. Rather, the company may argue, the Constitution also requires them to show a financial or physical injury, such as identity theft. This is one of the problems in our legal system that limited[17] the recently proposed settlement of the Equifax data breach litigation. (Don't forget to file[18] your settlement claim against Equifax.)The New Appellate Court Ruling in PatelOn August 8, a unanimous three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit held[19] that the Patel plaintiffs have constitutional standing to sue Facebook for violating their statutory privacy rights under BIPA. In doing so, the appellate court forcefully explained the hazards of face surveillance and the importance of BIPA's privacy protections.The court presented centuries of history of U.S. legal protections for privacy, sounding in the common law and the Constitution. For example, in the context of the Fourth Amendment, the Supreme Court has repeatedly held that 'advances in technology can increase the potential for unreasonable intrusions into personal privacy.' The appellate court cited the Supreme Court's protection of the public from home-intruding heat detectors in Kyllo v. United States[20] (2001), GPS location tracking in United States v. Jones[21] (2012), cellphone searches in Riley v. California[22] (2014), and cell-tower location tracking in Carpenter v. United States[23] (2018). The court held that 'an invasion of an individual's biometric privacy rights has a close relationship to a harm that has traditionally been regarded as providing a basis for a lawsuit in English or American courts.' Quoting Carpenter[24], the court explained that biometric information is 'detailed, encyclopedic, and effortlessly compiled.' Most importantly, the appellate court explained the grave privacy threats posed by Facebook's face surveillance: Once a face template of an individual is created, Facebook can use it to identify that individual in any of the other hundreds of millions of photos uploaded to Facebook each day, as well as determine when the individual was present at a specific location. Facebook can also identify the individual's Facebook friends or acquaintances who are present in the photo. Taking into account the future development of such technology as suggested in Carpenter, it seems likely that a face-mapped individual could be identified from a surveillance photo taken on the streets or in an office building. Or a biometric face template could be used to unlock the face recognition lock on that individual's cell phone. We conclude that the development of a face template using facial-recognition technology without consent (as alleged here) invades an individual's private affairs and concrete interests. The appellate court also upheld the trial court's certification of a class of Facebook users. Facebook reportedly[25] plans to seek review by the full appellate court. EFF filed an amicus brief[26] in Patel regarding the privacy menace of face surveillance, along with the ACLU, its Illinois and California affiliates, CDT, and Illinois PIRG.Lessons For LegislatorsEspecially after the new Patel decision, Illinois' BIPA is one of the most important data privacy laws in the country. What lessons does BIPA hold for legislators who want to better protect their constituents from corporations that place their profits before our privacy? First, a privacy law is only as strong as its enforcement tools, and the best enforcement tool is a private right of action[27]. In many cases, government agencies can't or won't enforce a statute. So people must be free to protect their own rights by filing their own lawsuits. Second, Congress must not pass a weak federal data privacy law that preempts[28] stronger state privacy laws. Many big tech companies told Congress for years that they could self-regulate. Now some of them are asking Congress for regulation. What changed? They want to dodge Illinois' BIPA and other state consumer data privacy laws, like California's Consumer Privacy Act[29] and Vermont's data broker registration statute[30]. Thus, opposition to preemption and support for private enforcement are EFFs two most important demands, among our many proposals[31] for new consumer data privacy legislation.Next stepsThe Ninth Circuit's new ruling in Patel is a watershed in privacy law. It allows litigation to go forward challenging Facebook's biometric surveillance of users absent their informed opt-in consent. It explains, more forcefully than any American appellate court opinion to date, the extraordinary privacy hazards of face surveillance. It holds that a loss of statutory privacy rights under Illinois BIPA is, by itself, a sufficient injury to show constitutional standing under Spokeo. And it clearly demonstrates the necessity of private rights of action, and why Congress must not preempt stronger state laws. Most importantly, it shows what all of us must do now: contact our federal and state legislators, and demand that they enact strong consumer data privacy laws. Illinois BIPA, as strengthened by Patel, is a model for others to follow.Adam Schwartz is a Senior Staff Attorney with the EFF's civil liberties team. urn:contentItem:60W0-7DS1-JDJN-64CS-00000-00Victory Square Provides Corporate Update on the Strong Performance of Portfolio Companies2020-09-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:01ZLexisNexisVictory Square Provides Corporate Update on the Strong Performance of Portfolio Companies

(GlobeNewswire) - Victory Square Technologies Inc. (Victory Squareor the Company) (CSE:VST) (OTC:VSQTF) (FWB:6F6), a company that builds and invests in cutting-edge technology that is shaping the 4th Industrial Revolution, today provided a corporate update on the strong performance of its portfolio companies.

During the first half of 2020, VSTs portfolio companies achieved significant milestones in terms of revenue growth, product development, and customer acquisition.

We were founded to give investors ground-floor access to the next generation of unicorn technology companies, before theyre unicorns, said Shafin Diamond Tejani, CEO of Victory Square Technologies. This is as much a priority today as it was 20 years ago. As big tech has surged during the pandemic, so many investors have been left on the sidelines, lamenting the inability to get in earlier on Amazon, Facebook, Alphabet and other tech giants. Our mission remains to democratize this kind of access to techs next big thing.

Victory Squares portfolio consists of companies powering the 4th Industrial Revolution, the wholesale transformation of society brought about by connected, digital technologies. Our businesses are not built around short-term plays or fleeting trends. 20+ portfolio companies that represent pillars of the future economy: digital health and diagnostics, artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), augmented and virtual reality (AR and VR), internet of things (IOT), cyber security, blockchain and more. The current crisis has already validated and accelerated many of the verticals and technologies that Victory Square invests in.

Here Are Some Highlights on 15 of Our Portfolio Companies:

Victory Square Health Inc. (Vertical: Digital Health, Diagnostics)

Victory Square Health Inc. was founded in 2016 to accelerate the development of personalized medicine and technology solutions including diagnostic tests to support patients care and improve health outcomes. Its first product, the Leishmaniasis Rapid Test, was developed in partnership with the UFMG, Federal University of Minas Gerais. Safetest took advantage of its expertise in the subject to develop other antibody-based tests and a robust R&D pipelines of diagnostic kits for Hansens Disease, Brucellosis, HTLV and Blood samples screening tests.

Highlights:

Safetest Covid-19 test enables the user to verify whether they are currently infected, have been infected or have never been infected with Covid-19.

Victory Square Health received US FDA permission to commence marketing, sales and distribution of Safetest Covid-19 Antibody Elisa Test under EUA.

Victory Square Health received Anvisa approval for Sale & Use of Safetest Covid-19 Antibody Elisa Test for the Country of Brazil.

First company to be approved in the Ideiagov program supported by the So Paulo State Government for immediate trials and application in the State.

Victory Square Health received CE from EU competent authority of Belgium for Safetest Elisa antibody test for distribution, sale, and usage throughout the 27 countries in the European Union.

Immersive Tech (Vertical: VR/AR/MR)

Immersive Tech designs, programs, builds and installs immersive and engaging experiences for some of the worlds leading companies for a variety of purposes such as brand engagement, revenue generation, and corporate training. Through a blend of video game development, theme park engineering and the latest VR/AR/MR technologies, the company has amassed a portfolio of global brands.

Highlights:

Recently completed new projects with three large multinational corporations (Capital One, Bayer, BioMrieux).

Won the 2019 Startup Canada High-Growth Entrepreneurship category.

Immersive new product presents the ultimate 5D experience that is 100% portable and brings major returns to the operator. Step inside a fully immersive AR experience as guests board Covid-19 safe teams as they are transported to one of over a dozen AR custom experiences including: Tourism attractions, Haunted Halloween, Santas village, The Temple of Doom, Peters Easter Land, The Sahara Desert, Commercial Events and Tradeshows and many more!

Aiming for a direct listing by Q4 2020/Q1 2021.

FansUnite Entertainment Inc. (Vertical: Sports Betting, eSports, Gaming)

FansUnite Entertainment Inc. (FansUnite) is a sports and entertainment company, focusing on technology related to regulated and lawful online gaming in sports, esports and casino. In addition to providing underlying technology, FansUnite operates multiple growing B2C brands. FansUnite adds value by acquiring and growing its gaming portfolio with high growth assets in new or developing markets.

Highlights:

Completed two financings totalling $8.3 million, with an oversubscribed brokered private placement led by Canaccord Genuity.

Acquisition of Askott Entertainment, a leading esports betting technology platform.

Acquisition of Mcbookie, a U.K. based sports book that has generated over $340M CAD in betting volume since inception.

Partnered with US based GameCo LLC to bring Askott technology into the US market.

CoPilot Advisor (Vertical: Automation, Artificial Intelligence)

CoPilot Advisor uses cutting edge A.I. technology to help sales teams automatically target qualified prospects on social media, initiate one-to-one conversations, and surface timely sales opportunities without requiring any content marketing, spam emails, or any advertising.

Highlights:

150% YOY growth over the past 12 months.

Clients include: MassMutual, Merrill Lynch, UBS, and New York Life, and more.

Finalist for the 2019 Technology Impact Awards for Company of the Year Startup Success.

V2 Games Inc. (Vertical: Mobile Gaming, eSports)

V2 Games is a video and mobile game ventures firm focusing on royalty investments in high-value gaming projects featuring globally-recognized intellectual properties. The company generates cash flow by streaming revenue share from recognizable gaming projects.

Highlights:

Projects include: Pacific Rim: Breach Wars, Rune: Ragnarok, Men In Black and Hello Kitty.

V2 Games previously developed the hit mobile game PAC-MAN Bounce, which got over 20 million downloads.

Aiming for a direct listing by Q4 2020/Q1 2021.

Taloflow.ai (Vertical: Cloud Infrastructure, Cloud Management)

Taloflows prediction engine reveals the cost of every cloud process in real-time, its an AI autopilot for cloud resource management that saves companies up to 40% on Amazon Web Services (AWS). Investors include: Victory Square Technologies; Plug and Play Ventures; Scott Belsky, Venture Partner at Benchmark; Ian Wong, Co-founder of Opendoor; David Tedman, co-founder of Hootsuite and Invoke; Ross Wightman, founding engineer of Avigilon; and John Seely Brown, Co-Chairman of Deloitte Edge.

Multapplied Networks (Vertical: SD-WAN)

Multapplied Networks Inc. develops and sells a proprietary Software-Defined Wide Area Network (SD-WAN) platform that Cloud and Managed Service Providers white-label and run in their infrastructure to improve visibility and control over end-customer experiences of their hosted, managed applications and drive customer acquisition, retention and brand. Monthly recurring revenue has increased 12% from FY2019.

Shape Immersive (Vertical: Augmented Reality, 3D Ecommerce)

Shape Immersive creates the value layer of spatial computing for the worlds top retailers and ecommerce brands. Our 3D commerce solution helps our customers increase conversion rates, drive more sales and reduce return rates with 3D and augmented reality technology. Clients include: Nike, Amazon, Lululemon, Disney, Intel, Red bull, TED, Uniqlo.

Aspen Technologies (Vertical: Cybersecurity)

Aspen is pioneering a cyber security offering for the new Work-From-Home (WFH) Covid-19 business world. Aspen delivers entrepreneurs and business professionals a way to ensure maximum productivity while collaborating through the cloud with colleagues, partners and customers.

Grow Tech Labs (Vertical: Plant-based Science)

GTL is a Plant-Based Science company focused on the R&D of cannabis and psychoactive compounds from both plant-based compounds and fungi as well as the development of skin products from plant-based derivatives.

Covalent (Vertical: Fintech)

Covalent is solving a large infrastructure problem that is inhibiting blockchain adoption. Fixing these problems will exponentially increase access to and adoption of distributed blockchain technologies for enterprise and consumer use cases.

Victory Square Entertainment (Vertical: Film, TV, Digital Content)

VSE was established to strengthen the VST presence in film, TV and other digital related content. VSE has three main areas of focus, script development, financing and production. Since inception, VSE has financed and produced three films which include Dragged Across the Concrete featuring Mel Gibson and Vince Vaughn, What They Had featuring two time academy award winner Hillary Swank and The Opening Act featuring Jimmy O. Yang, Cedric the Entertainer and Ken Jeong.

CloudAdvisors (Vertical: Insurance Tech)

CloudAdvisors is one of the top InsurTech solutions in North America, powering the next-generation of Employee Benefit Advisors. CloudAdvisors connect insurance advisors with marketplace data and the best tools in a secure digital platform for an enhanced client experience. Through digital client management, on-demand insights, automated reporting, governance and compliance, CloudAdvisors create an accessible and intelligent robo-advice assistant for better insurance advice.

Compression.AI (Vertical: Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning)

Accelerating businesses digital experiences, Compression AI utilizes its proprietary neural networks to tailor compression algorithms to each and every input resulting in compressed data sizes as little as 10% of the original 2020 Global Data Point.
