urn:contentItem:5XYG-6MR1-JCMN-Y0F1-00000-00[VIDEO] Laura Ingraham Warns Trump His 'America Last' Foreign Worker Visas Could Cost Him Votes in 20202020-01-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:01ZLexisNexis[VIDEO] Laura Ingraham Warns Trump His 'America Last' Foreign Worker Visas Could Cost Him Votes in 2020AC Young

Jan 11, 2020( WayneDupree.com: https://www.waynedupree.com Delivered by Newstex) AdvertisementStaunch conservative warriors Laura Ingraham, Michelle Malkin, and Lou Dobbs took to the airwaves yesterday to issue a stark warning to President Trump over his proposed massive cheap labor giveaway to Big Tech Oligarchs that is guaranteed to devastate the American worker. The GOP Establishment's proposal to import millions of indentured servants on F-1 visas is expected to drive down wages for recent college graduates and tech workers, and cause many more Americans to be forced to train their foreign replacements. RELATED: Pres. Trump — If You Want American Visa, Prove You Can Obtain Health Insurance[1] It is easy for conservatives and America First populists to get swept up in the day to day news cycle, and forget that it is our job to keep our great president honest by making known our needs and concerns.

Unfortunately, the President resorted to cheap pabulum and Chamber of Commerce talking points in arguing to allow massive hordes of high-skilled tech workers from India, and other countries, to flood into America, driving down wages and taking jobs from American men who wish to start and support families. I don't blame the president for this. I blame his advisers from the GOP Establishment who are trying to trick this president into putting oligarchic special interests above the interests of our great middle class.Laura Ingraham held President Trump's feet to the fire here:God Bless You @IngrahamAngle[2] for Holding Pres. Trump's Feet to the Fire on His Immigration Promises! Laura expresses the concerns of many America First Conservatives at the WH's plan to import more foreign "high-tech" workers to compete w/ Americans. "You ran on America First." pic.twitter.com/zExw2uXKqE[3];— The Columbia Bugle (@ColumbiaBugle) January 11, 2020[4]AdvertisementMore from Wayne Dupree [Twitter Link][5]Advertisement Michelle Malkin explained in more detail just why this visa program is so devastating for the American worker:Remember the other night when I pointed out Ivanka's stupid Open Borders Inc. propaganda at CES about wanting to keep every last foreign student in the country here to take jobs — when she said her father agreed with her that it was 'insane' not to open the floodgates? The exchange with Laura Ingraham last night proves that President Trump has, in fact, swallowed whole the Chamber of Commerce/NSF/Javanka/Tim Cook myth of the American tech worker shortage hook, line, and America Last sinker. The reason this all matters is that the F-1 program will dwarf H-1B as a bottomless pipeline for cheap foreign workers. Unlike H-1B, which at least has a nominal cap, F-1 is unlimited. UNLIMITED. [Telegram[6]]Advertisement That's right, folks. This foreign visa worker program will create an endless pipeline of cheap foreign workers to take away good American middle-class jobs. Those who do finally find a job will find themselves slaving away for wages that are far too low to start a family. This is a disgrace and a betrayal of our great young people.David North, a fellow at the Center for Immigration Studies (CIS) and noted scholar on immigration and its influence on domestic policies, said at the National Press Club this week that a government program cooked up during the George W. Bush administration and put into place through a federal regulation encourages U.S. businesses to hire foreign instead of citizen college graduates. North also said at the panel discussion, hosted by CIS, that millions of dollars a year is diverted from helping Americans to benefiting F-1 student visa holders and the American companies that hire them. The students, North said, get to work for one year or more at an American business, and the business that hires them gets a discount under the Optional Practical Training (OPT) protocol that allows them not to pay certain payroll taxes for their non-immigrant, non-citizen employees. 'You shouldn't take money from America's elderly, give it to fat cat corporations so that they can discriminate against Americans,' North said. 'I don't think that's a very good idea.' [Breitbart[7]]AdvertisementWhat's more, according to recent statistics, there is NO LABOR SHORTAGE, as President Trump has claimed:There remain more than 11 million Americans who are out of work but want full-time jobs, despite claims by corporate interests and the big business lobby of a so-called 'labor shortage.' The latest unemployment data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics reveals there is still slack in the labor market for disenfranchised Americans to enter the workforce rather than business bringing foreign workers to the U.S. to take jobs. [Breitbart[8]].@LouDobbs[9] calls out Senator Mike Lee on @FoxNews[10]: pic.twitter.com/vJ6wJmni3f[11]; — U.S. Tech Workers (@USTechWorkers) January 9, 2020[12]Advertisement [Twitter Link][13] To add insult to injury, this program is totally rife with fraud. F-1 visa holders from countries like India and China are overstaying their visa by pretending to work for fake companies. President Trump has to put an end to this madness immediately.WASHINGTON — A federal visa program allowing international students to work at firms in the United States after graduation appears to have been exploited by fake companies providing false employment verifications,according to an NBC News/NBC Bay Area investigation. The F-1visa program includes a component that allows students to stay in the U.S. to get practical work experience after obtaining their professional degrees. Many students, schools and employers use the program legitimately, as intended. But a recent federal prosecution revealed the potential for fraud, with a defendant admitting in court papers she had provided false employment records for nearly 2,700 students. [NBC][14]I am the biggest supporter of President Trump on God's green earth, and I happen to believe that the Chamber of Commerce and GOP Establishment have tried to trick Trump on this issue. I truly believe that if we cry out to our great president, he will hear our voices and put an end to this oligarchic nonsense, and do the right thing for the American people. Will you join me? Call the White House now: Comments: 202-456-1111 Switchboard: 202-456-1414Attn: Wayne Dupree is a free speech champion who works tirelessly to bring you news that the mainstream media ignores. But he needs your support in order to keep delivering quality, independent journalism. You can make a huge impact in the war against fake news by pledging as little as $5 per month. Please click here Patreon.com/WDShow[15] to help Wayne battle the fake news media.; [ 1]: https://www.waynedupree.com/trump-order-denies-visas-immigrants/ [ 2]:   https://twitter.com/IngrahamAngle?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 3]:   https://t.co/zExw2uXKqE [ 4]:   https://twitter.com/ColumbiaBugle/status/1215848646190616577?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 5]:   https://twitter.com/ColumbiaBugle/status/1215848646190616577 [ 6]:   https://t.me/MichelleMalkin/149 [ 7]:   https://www.breitbart.com/politics/2019/08/23/immigration-expert-government-program-incentivizes-employers-to-discriminate-against-citizen-college-grads/ [ 8]:   https://www.breitbart.com/politics/2020/01/10/no-labor-shortage-11m-americans-out-of-work-but-all-want-full-time-jobs/ [ 9]:   https://twitter.com/LouDobbs?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 10]:   https://twitter.com/FoxNews?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 11]:   https://t.co/vJ6wJmni3f [ 12]:   https://twitter.com/USTechWorkers/status/1215104410466095105?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 13]:   https://twitter.com/USTechWorkers/status/1215104410466095105 [ 14]:   https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/immigration/thousands-foreign-students-u-s-student-visas-may-have-worked-n1109286 [ 15]:   https://www.patreon.com/wdshow

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5J98-P8Y1-JBHT-D2TN-00000-00Video on demand2016-01-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:01ZLexisNexisPg. 10Video on demandLiisa RajalaConcordABSTRACT

[...]what they do is take their live program and. before it goes to a live venue, they'll shoot dark matches, and these matches are not shown on the TV as a live event, but they're recorded onto a hard disk. Bowker's projects can be as small as connecting a half-dozen cables across a TV studio to building a production tractor-trailer used to broadcast major league sports events.

FULL TEXT

Hudson company's engineering skills give broadcasters an edge

From the perspective of WWE fans, the moment the wrestling network converted from standard-definition television to high-definition in 2008 was as easy as flicking a switch. That was the final step, but as lan Bowker, president and founder of Hudson-based Icon Broadcast, explains, there's more behind what meets the eye.

"It took 18 months of preparation,'' says Bowker, who was consulted to design, build and train the people to run the system out of WWE's studio in Stanford, Conn. Since then, Bowker has worked with the network on an HD shared editing project, allowing WWE to edit its live broadcasts to fit the cultures and regulations of its 46 markets.

"For example," explains Bowker, "in Germany, you're not allowed to show, blood at a live sporting event. In Saudi Arabia you're not allowed to show bare skin on a woman. So what they do is take their live program and. before it goes to a live venue, they'll shoot dark matches, and these matches are not shown on the TV as a live event, but they're recorded onto a hard disk. [Then] they're put into this shared editing pool and they'll recut or reedit the live event to be redistributed in other markets."

Bowker says for every match the WWE may do four dark matches and record them onto the video server to allow specific versions for each country.

"Within 48 hours of a live event in the U.S., WWE puts that back into its big video server in Stanford, Conn., and it's edited for all these different markets and then delivered either electronically or cut back to tape and issued to the country - and that's done for 46 countries," says Bowker.

Bowker's projects can be as small as connecting a half-dozen cables across a TV studio to building a production tractor-trailer used to broadcast major league sports events.

Olympics broadcast

His most recent project has Bowker managing the buildout of New England Cable News' studio in Newton, Mass., which will take about nine months, he says. NBC recently announced that NECN will replace Channel 7 News out of Boston at the end of the year.

"At the moment, NECN is a 24-hour news channel, so what you'll probably see is the news that goes out becomes the main Boston news for NBC," says Bowker.

He is also working on a project to help broadcast the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil back to the U.S.

"I'm building what they call flypacks, so when broadcasters go down to the Olympics, they typically take cases of the equipment that's pre-wired, and they just put big connectors between the cases to hook them up that will provide the signal to bring it back to the home country," explains Bowker.

Fifty pieces of equipment will be in the four flypacks, but it will take only a half-hour to connect them to each other and the cameras. It would take all week if they were wired on the spot, says Bowker. It's also not practical logistically to wire on the spot, since there are different venues so the broadcasters will move around nearly every week.

Game Creek relationship

Bowker has always worked in technical broadcast engineering positions, though in a variety of roles. Born in England, he started his career working for the U.K. government on aircraft flight trials.

"My role was more of doing these flight trials and filming them, and the more I got into that, from film it became video and then editing them, and I ended up leaving that role and running a film and TV unit for the police in the U.K., and then I left them and went to train at the BBC," he says.

Bowker left the BBC for private sector- technical roles, which led to working on a three-year project for Avid Technology in Tewksbury, Mass., in the mid-90s. He returned to the U.S. shortly after with another company and ran a technical broadcast engineering team for a big broadcast company. But in 2006, the company was bought out by Thomson Broadcast, a French conglomerate.

"I was laying people off every month," says Bowker, who called such a task demoralizing. That same year, Bowker resigned after being asked to head up another layoff. "I said, 'You can have my salary and distribute it among these guys."

That's when Bowker started Icon Broadcast in Hudson. WWE reached out to him, having known him from consulting them for several years. Shortly thereafter it built a mobile production unit for HD provider Game Creek Video - another Hudson-based company. Since then, Bowker has built all but two of the company's mobile units.

That's 46 trailers since 2006, plus 90 small news trucks in the past year alone.

Ebbs and flows

There are about 17,000 or 18,000 cables in each vehicle, and every cable is labeled, meaning there are 34,000 labels that have to be printed and attached to wires, says Bowker.

"It's a big jigsaw puzzle in making sure everything gets done and gets done quickly," he says.

A large trailer will take four months to be built in Ohio, during which Icon Broadcast's team will fly out to Ohio to inspect it. Then the vehicle comes to New Hampshire for a 10-week build cycle with seven to eight people work- ing full time to install the wiring, followed by a threeweek test cycle.

There are only a dozen or so companies like Icon Broadcast, says Bowker, who adds that networks like NBC stopped running their own trailers about 20 years ago and instead leased vehicles and engineers through middlemen like Game Creek Video.

Bowker says the ebbs and flows of the business make it more practical to lease out the equipment and expertise, including smaller stations, like New York's public television channel, WNET.

"Although the TV industry as a whole is a roller coaster ride, what I found, certainly for me as a business owner, is year on year I've been doubling my numbers," says Bowker. "It's been a wild ride for the last 10 years. The volume of business that I'm doing is just incredible."

The industry has evolved as well during Bowker's career.

"When I started, it was all analog pictures and fuzzy pictures on home screens and now it's 4K and 8K ultrahigh-definition and things like that crystal-clear pictures," says Bowker. "But the big tech breakthrough that's starting to occur in our industry is video over IP, so using a network connection like you would do in your house but a wired network connection to send videos over with audio."

At the beginning of the year, Icon built the first IP truck in the country for Game Creek Video, which went to Fox Sports.

"This is a huge step forward in reducing the weight of the trailers, increasing the amount of pictures you can display - moving pictures around from the truck to a studio location, you can send it over a dedicated IP line. It just opens up a whole world in our industry," says Bowker. "We're able to be on the technological forefront, which is fun too."

There's more behind what meets then eye.

"Its a big jigsaw puzzle in making sure everything gets done ana gets done quickly.' - IAN BOWKER

Liisa Rajala can be reached at lrajala@nhbr.com

urn:contentItem:5W4N-SHT1-DY9S-T131-00000-00Video plans & items as of 5:00 p.m. ET Friday, May 17;Video plans & items as of 5:00 p.m. ET Friday, May 172019-05-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:01ZLexisNexisADVISORIES,NATIONALVideo plans & items as of 5:00 p.m. ET Friday, May 17Video plans & items as of 5:00 p.m. ET Friday, May 17The Canadian Press

For editorial questions regarding video, please contact Director of News Photography Graeme Roy at 416-507-2167 or graeme.roy(at)thecanadianpress.com.

For technical support, please call our 24/7 help desk at 1-800-268-8149 or 416-507-2099.

---

Latest video from the Canadian Press:

Headline: RCMP video should shock Canadians: Sinclair

Caption: Former Truth and Reconciliation commissioner Murray Sinclair says a video of a Mountie interrogating a young Indigenous woman disclosing sexual abuse in B.C. foster care brings home in a "visceral way" a reality that Canadians should be shocked by and one that they need to see. The 2012 video was released publicly by APTN this week as a result of a court proceeding and has prompted political reaction. Sinclair tells The Canadian Press in an interview that the video should cause Canadians to be more supportive of those who say police officers require more oversight.

Filename: n_RCMP-Sinclair20190517T1625

Companion: RCMP-Sinclair

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:25 p.m. ET Friday, May 17

Headline: Mark Norman affair needs public inquiry, Scheer says

Caption: Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer says Canada needs a public inquiry into the case of Vice-Admiral Mark Norman. On Parliament Hill Friday, Scheer says a full investigation is justified to examine how the military's former second-in-command came to be charged with over alleged leaks of cabinet secrets about a shipbuilding contract. The case against Norman collapsed last week after Crown prosecutors got new information from the defence that convinced them they stood no reasonable chance of landing a conviction.

Filename: n_Scheer-Mark-Norman20190517T1549

Companion: Mark-Norman

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 3:49 p.m. ET Friday, May 17

Headline: Scheer speaks as long-awaited end to Canada's tariff standoff with U.S. finally at hand

Caption: Canada's year-long standoff with the Trump administration over punitive U.S. steel and aluminum tariffs is finally over, sources say, removing a key hurdle in efforts to ratify the new North American trade pact. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau was to make an unscheduled, last-minute trip to Hamilton, Canada's steel-manufacturing capital, to confirm the breakthrough at an event at steel giant Stelco. Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer spoke about the tariffs issue in Ottawa prior to Trudeau's statement.

Filename: n_Scheer-Cda-US-Tariffs20190517T1400

Companion: Cda-US-Tariffs

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 2:00 p.m. ET Friday, May 17

Headline: Conservatives prod Liberals over report Trudeau pushed Norman leak

Caption: The Mark Norman affair dominated question period Friday in the House of Commons, fueled by a report in the Globe and Mail newspaper that Prime Minister Justin Trudeau pushed for an investigation over the leak of cabinet secrets regarding a $700 million shipbuilding contract.

Filename: n_Norman-Bezan-Chagger20190517T1303

Companion: Mark-Norman

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 1:03 p.m. ET Friday, May 17

COMING UP LATER (Subject to frequent change):

Hamilton, Ont. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau makes an unscheduled, last-minute trip to Hamilton, Canada's steel-manufacturing capital. (expected next)

AVAILABLE ON THE RAW CHANNEL:

Long: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau arrives at l'Élysée for the Christchurch Call meeting (May 15)

Long: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau attends a reception with the Croatian-Canadian community in honour of the visit of the President of Croatia (Video from May 14, published May 15)

Long: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau speaks at the Canadian Home Builders' Association national conference (May 9)

Long: B.C. Conservative MP Mark Warawa bids teary farewell to House of Commons (May 8)

Note: Please contact Graeme Roy at graeme.roy@thecanadianpress.com for editorial video-related questions.

Please contact donald.wright@thecanadianpress.com if you have questions about logging into the new CP Video Centre (http://www.thecanadianpress.com/videocentre).

For technical support, please call our 24/7 help desk at 1-800-268-8149 or 416-507-2099, or email support@thecanadianpress.com

SENT PREVIOUSLY:

Headline: Dan Aykroyd on reviving 'Ghostbusters' for a new generation

Caption: Dan Aykroyd says he "proudly" counts 2016's female-centric "Ghostbusters" as part of the pantheon: "I like my girl Ghostbusters." He discusses the 1984 original ghost-comedy, director Paul Feig's revival and the new "Ghostbusters" movie which Aykroyd will be producing.

Filename: e_Aykroyd-Ghostbusters20190517T0900

Companion: FILM-Aykroyd-Ghostbusters

Category: ENTERTAINMENT

Time Published: 9:00 a.m. ET Friday, May 17

Headline: N.L. party leaders react to Liberal minority win

Caption: Newfoundland and Labrador elected a rare minority government Thursday night. Dwight Ball's Liberals squeaked by with a diminished seat count while Progressive Conservative Leader Ches Crosbie said he hopes to topple the government within a year.

Filename: n_NL-Election20190517T0815

Companion: NL-Elxn

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 8:15 a.m. ET Friday, May 17

Headline: Conservative MP says Trudeau acting like a 'coward' on China detentions

Caption: Conservative House leader Candice Bergen draws the ire of Speaker Geoff Regan after she says Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is acting like a coward in dealing with China. Declining relations between the two countries slid lower Thursday after Canadians Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor were formally arrested after months in Chinese detention.

Filename: n_Bergen-Cda-China20190516T1648

Companion: Cda-China

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:48 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Liberals say they want Senate to revive tanker ban bill

Caption: Terry Beech, Transport Minister Marc Garneau's parliamentary secretary, says the government hopes the Senate continues debate on a bill that would ban oil tankers along parts of the B.C. coast. In response to a Conservative question, Beech also says the government will consider amendments reflecting the spirit of the legislation.

Filename: n_Environment-Assessment-Bill20190516T1615

Companion: Environment-Assessment-Bill

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:15 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Scheer promises energy corridor; Morneau says Scheer has 'no credible' economic plan

Caption: Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer says Canada needs a coast-to-coast energy corridor where it would be easy to build pipelines and power lines. In a speech laying out his economic vision before the next election, the opposition leader says having one dedicated route would make it easier to approve major new energy projects. Finance Minister Bill Morneau responded to Scheer's plan, saying the pipeline plan is a "risky" approach.

Filename: n_Scheer-Economics-Morneau20190516T1602

Companion: Scheer-Economics

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:02 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau talks at VivaTech in Paris, meets with startups

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says he is confident a new digital charter being launched by Canada will make the internet a safer place. Speaking at the VivaTech conference in Paris today, Trudeau says the framework will dictate how the country will combat hate speech, misinformation and online electoral interference in Canada. After the announcement, Trudeau met with representatives from Canadian startups and tech companies.

Filename: n_Trudeau-VivaTech-Paris20190516T1525

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 3:25 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau meets with Macron at l'Élysée

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met with French president Emmanuel Macron at l'Élysée in Paris. Trudeau says the two leaders talked about their common goal of better regulating the web against hateful speech in the wake of the Christchurch Call.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Macron20190516T1420

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 2:20 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau on Canada's new digital plan and support on the 'Christchurch Call'

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says a new digital charter will dictate how the country will combat hate speech, misinformation and online electoral interference in Canada. He made the announcement at a technology conference in Paris. The move comes after signing on to the "Christchurch Call" - a pledge involving several world leaders and internet giants to stop the spread of hate online.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Paris-Internet20190516T1416

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 2:16 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau says he will work with allies to help detainees in China

Caption: In a news conference in Paris, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau spoke gravely but in vague terms about how Canada might respond to the arrests of two Canadians in China. Canadians Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor have been formally arrested after months in Chinese detention. Trudeau says Canada will work with allies to help the two men.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Paris-China20190516T1409

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris, Cda-China

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 2:09 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Bank of Canada: Mortgage stress test has improved quality of lending but continued vigilance is important

Caption: The Bank of Canada released its annual Financial System Review on Thursday. Bank of Canada governor Stephen Poloz highlighted the effect of the mortgage stress test, as well as the current state of regional housing markets.

Filename: n_BoC-Poloz20190516T1300

Companion: BoC-FSR-Risks

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 1:00 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau meets with New Zealand prime minister in Paris

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met with New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern on Thursday at the Canadian Residence in Paris. The two spoke about New Zealand's plan for dealing with hate and extremism online in the wake of the Christchurch mosque attacks on March 19, 2019.

Filename: n_PMJT-Paris-Ardern20190516T0930

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 9:30 a.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Veterinarians brought dogs to Parliament Hill to campaign for medical cannabis for pets

Caption: Five dogs were a big hit on Parliament Hill as veterinarians lobbied for legal changes that would allow them to prescribe medical cannabis for animals. They stood outside the main doors of West Block, capturing the oohs and ahs of politicians and staff as they emerged after question period Wednesday.

Filename: n_Stampede-Food20190515T1945

Companion: Stampede-Food

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 7:45 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Calgary Stampede unveils its midway food list for 2019

Caption: This year's midway menu at the Calgary Stampede includes ice pops made from pickle juice, deep-fried chicken skin and octopus deep-fried or in a lollipop. The 10-day festival celebrating the cowboy life tries to outdo itself each year in its culinary offerings. Octopus will have a strong showing this summer, as will hearts - be they the deep-fried centres of artichokes or barbecued chicken hearts on a stick.

Filename: n_Stampede-Food20190515T1945

Companion: Stampede-Food

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 7:45 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Bains on tech giants, Christchurch Call

Caption: Canada's Minister of Innovation, Navdeep Bains, answered questions from reporters about being too soft on big tech companies such as Facebook. He was participating in a G7 meeting while Prime Minister Justin Trudeau was in Paris for the "Christchurch Call."

Filename: n_Bains-Tech-Data20190515T1745

Companion: Big-Data-Strategy

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 5:45 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Singh goes after Liberals over Phoenix fiasco

Caption: Public Services Minister Carla Qualtrough says the Liberals are keeping IBM accountable for failures with the Phoenix pay system. The company is getting more money to work on Phoenix even as the government works to replace what NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh describes as a mess.

Filename: n_Singh-Qualtrough-IBM20190515T1700

Companion: -

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 5:00 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Goodale calls RCMP interrogation video of Indigenous assault victim 'abhorrent'

Caption: Public Safety Minister Ralph Goodale is denouncing an aggressive 2012 interrogation of an under-age Indigenous sexual assault victim, following a story from and footage obtained by Aboriginal Peoples Television Network. Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer used the issue as his first question in question period after the details in the APTN story outraged MPs on Parliament Hill Wednesday.

Filename: n_Question-Period-RCMP-Goodale20190515T1651

Companion: -

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:51 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Tories ask Liberals to televise hearing on Mark Norman affair

Caption: Conservative defence critic James Bezan takes his turn in question period to ask the chair of the national defence committee to televise Thursday's meeting where MPs will debate an investigation of the Mark Norman affair. In response, government House leader Bardish Chagger says it's up to the committee.

Filename: n_Question-Period-Bezan-Norman20190515T1634

Companion: -

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:34 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: B.C. to hold money laundering public inquiry; final report due May 2021

Caption: Premier John Horgan has called a public inquiry into money laundering in British Columbia following three independent reviews that found money laundering in the province's real estate market and other sectors of the economy worth billions of dollars annually.

Filename: n_Money-Laundering-B.C.20190515T1600

Companion: Money-Laundering-BC

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:00 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Canadian Forest Service officials discuss this year's wildfire season

Caption: Canadian Forest Service have an update on the forecast for this year's fire season. According to Richard Carr, wildland fire analyst at Northern Forestry Centre, more western regions in Canada have an increase risk in fire severity. Ellen Whitman, fire research assistant at the Northern Forestry Centre, says that one of the main reasons for an increase of fires in Canada is due to climate change.

Filename: n_Wildfire-Forecast20190515T1540

Companion: Wildfire-Forecast

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 3:40 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Environment minister criticizes Conservative opponents on climate change

Caption: Environment Minister Catherine McKenna criticizes Opposition leader Andrew Scheer, Ontario Premier Doug Ford and Alberta Premier Jason Kenney over their climate change positions.

Filename: n_McKenna-Climate20190515T1317

Companion: McKenna-Climate-Motion

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 1:17 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Trudeau tours Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau took a tour of Paris's famed Notre Dame Cathedral, alongside Canada's French ambassador Isabelle Hudon, Notre-Dame de Paris' rector and archpriest, Patrick Chauvet, and France's Minister of Culture, Franck Riester. The iconic monument that was partially destroyed by fire in mid-April. Trudeau says it was an honour to be able to exhibit some of the solidarity Canadians feel toward their French cousins.

Filename: n_Trudeau-NotreDame20190515T1215

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 12:15 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Trudeau arrives in Paris

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has landed in Paris for a two-day visit that will include a summit later today about preventing violent extremist acts from being streamed online. As he stepped out of the plane, he was greeted by French ambassador Isabelle Hudon and chief of protocol Shannon Jinadasa.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Paris20190515T0820

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 8:20 a.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Goodale says feds will defend against any legal action from Tori Stafford killer

Caption: Public Safety Minister Ralph Goodale says the federal government will defend itself against any legal action from Terri-Lynne McClintic, who was sentenced to life in prison in 2010 for her role in the first-degree murder of eight-year-old Tori Stafford. During question period Tuesday, Conservative MP Glen Motz asked about McClintic, whose transfer to an Indigenous healing lodge was reversed following a public outcry last year.

Filename: n_QP-Stafford-Goodale20190514T1701

Companion: McClintic-Prison

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 5:01 p.m. ET Tuesday, May 14

Headline: Trudeau faces off with Scheer, Singh for first time since Norman case dropped

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau faces off with Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer and NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh in the House of Commons for the first time since federal prosecutors dropped the breach-of-trust case against Vice-Admiral Mark Norman - and the issue dominated much of a boisterous question period.

Filename: n_QP-Scheer-Singh-Trudeau20190514T1545

Companion: Mark-Norman

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 3:45 p.m. ET Tuesday, May 14

Headline: Goodale avoids responding to Norman-case fallout

Caption: Federal cabinet is meeting in Ottawa today, and Chief of the Defence Staff Jonathan Vance and Jody Thomas, the deputy minister of defence, were both summoned to attend, a week after the criminal case against Vice-Admiral Mark Norman was stayed. Public Safety Minister Ralph Goodale says he will not comment on the quality of the RCMP investigation in the Norman case.

Filename: n_Mark-Norman-Cabinet20190514T1245

Companion: Mark-Norman

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 12:45 p.m. ET Tuesday, May 14

Headline: Dr. Ruth Westheimer on new doc 'Ask Dr. Ruth' and making her 'dent' in society

Caption: Sex therapist Dr. Ruth Westheimer says "the timing is right" for a new doc on her life, "Ask Dr. Ruth."

Filename: e_Film-Dr-Ruth20190514T0800

Companion: FILM-Ask-Dr-Ruth

Category: ENTERTAINMENT

Time Published: 8:00 a.m. ET Tuesday, May 14

Headline: Alex Trebek in Ottawa to open Royal Canadian Geographical Society's new HQ

Caption: 'Jeopardy!' host Alex Trebek visits Ottawa

NEW Filename: n_TV-Alex-Trebek-Ottawa20190514T0800

Companion: TV-Alex-Trebek-Ottawa

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 8:00 a.m. ET Tuesday, May 14

Headline: Jagmeet Singh says Liberals, Tories have same plan for climate change

Caption: NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh asked the Liberals to agree to declare a climate emergency and commit to stronger emissions targets. Liberal Health Minister Ginette Petipas-Taylor says the Liberals have a strong plan with over 50 measures to tackle climate change.

Filename: n_QP-Singh-Climate20190513T1634

Companion: Climate-Change-NDP

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:34 p.m. ET Monday, May 13

Headline: Museum in Neil Armstrong's hometown ready to celebrate 50th anniversary of first moon landing

Caption: This July marks 50 years since Neil Armstrong became the first man to walk on the moon. The Armstrong Air and Space Museum in his hometown of Wapakoneta, Ohio offers a unique insight into that event and the life of Neil Armstrong.

Filename: e_TRAVEL-Log-Neil-Armstrong20190513T0900

Companion: TRAVEL-Log-Neil-Armstrong

Category: ENTERTAINMENT

Time Published: 9:00 a.m. ET Monday, May 13

Headline: Kawhi Leonard buzzer-beater lifts Raptors to Game 7 win over Philadelphia 76ers

Caption: Kawhi Leonard scored a buzzer-beating jump shot to lift the Raptors 92-90 over the Philadelphia 76ers and into the Eastern Conference finals for the second time in franchise history. Leonard's shot bounced four times on the rim before falling, and he says the moment will be a highlight of his career. It was the first buzzer-beater in a Game 7 in NBA history. The Raptors face the Bucks in the finals, starting Wednesday in Milwaukee.

Filename: s_BKN-76ers-Raptors20190513T0900

Companion: BKN-76ers-Raptors

Category: SPORTS

Time Published: 9:00 a.m. ET Monday, May 13

Headline: Trudeau talks jobs, calls money laundering report alarming during stop in Alberta

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau came to Edmonton Friday, meeting with Mayor Don Iveson. He discussed new job numbers and a report out of British Columbia this week on the impact of money laundering on the economy, especially B.C. house prices. Trudeau also addressed the recent Alberta election and prospects for his Liberals in upcoming federal campaign.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Jobs-Alberta20190510T1631

Companion: Money-Laundering-BC, StatCan-Jobs

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:31 p.m. ET Friday, May 10

Headline: Hockey Hall of Famer Red Kelly laid to rest

Caption: A funeral for hockey great Red Kelly was held on Friday in Toronto. Kelly, who starred for the Detroit Red Wings and Toronto Maple Leafs, has died at age 91.

Filename: s_HKN-Red-Kelly-Funeral20190510T1427

Companion: HKN-Red-Kelly-Funeral

Category: SPORTS

Time Published: 2:27 p.m. ET Friday, May 10

Headline: Veterans Affairs taken to task for online Second World War video featuring German soldiers

Caption: Veterans Affairs Minister Lawrence MacAulay apologizes for a mistake where footage of German troops, not Canadian soldiers, was used in an online video to mark 74 years since the end of fighting in Europe during the Second World War. Under questioning in the House of Commons, MacAulay says he has asked for a review and doesn't want the error to detract from the message to ensure the atrocities of that war never happen again. Later, former Conservative defence minister Rob Nicholson can be seen standing and applauding MacAulay's comments.

Filename: n_War-German-Video20190510T1213

Companion: -

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 12:13 p.m. ET Friday, May 10

Headline: Trudeau calls on all political leaders to denounce hate and Islamophobia

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau attended a community Iftar dinner Thursday and praised Canada's Pakistani community. He denounced all forms of Islamophobia and says that all political leaders must call it out when they see it.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Islamophobia20190510T1000

Companion: -

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 10:00 a.m. ET Friday, May 10

Headline: Trudeau appearance at Liberal event interrupted by Grassy Narrows protester

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's armchair discussion with Liberal MP Adam Vaughan at an event with party supporters in Toronto was interrupted by a Grassy Narrows protester.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Protester20190510T0845

Companion: Grassy-Narrows

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 8:45 p.m. ET Friday, May 10

Latest video from the Canadian Press:

Headline: Conservative MP says Trudeau acting like a 'coward' on China detentions

Caption: Conservative House leader Candice Bergen draws the ire of Speaker Geoff Regan after she says Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is acting like a coward in dealing with China. Declining relations between the two countries slid lower Thursday after Canadians Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor were formally arrested after months in Chinese detention.

Filename: n_Bergen-Cda-China20190516T1648

Companion: Cda-China

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:48 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Liberals say they want Senate to revive tanker ban bill

Caption: Terry Beech, Transport Minister Marc Garneau's parliamentary secretary, says the government hopes the Senate continues debate on a bill that would ban oil tankers along parts of the B.C. coast. In response to a Conservative question, Beech also says the government will consider amendments reflecting the spirit of the legislation.

Filename: n_Environment-Assessment-Bill20190516T1615

Companion: Environment-Assessment-Bill

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:15 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Scheer promises energy corridor; Morneau says Scheer has 'no credible' economic plan

Caption: Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer says Canada needs a coast-to-coast energy corridor where it would be easy to build pipelines and power lines. In a speech laying out his economic vision before the next election, the opposition leader says having one dedicated route would make it easier to approve major new energy projects. Finance Minister Bill Morneau responded to Scheer's plan, saying the pipeline plan is a "risky" approach.

Filename: n_Scheer-Economics-Morneau20190516T1602

Companion: Scheer-Economics

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:02 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau talks at VivaTech in Paris, meets with startups

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says he is confident a new digital charter being launched by Canada will make the internet a safer place. Speaking at the VivaTech conference in Paris today, Trudeau says the framework will dictate how the country will combat hate speech, misinformation and online electoral interference in Canada. After the announcement, Trudeau met with representatives from Canadian startups and tech companies.

Filename: n_Trudeau-VivaTech-Paris20190516T1525

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 3:25 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau meets with Macron at l'Élysée

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met with French president Emmanuel Macron at l'Élysée in Paris. Trudeau says the two leaders talked about their common goal of better regulating the web against hateful speech in the wake of the Christchurch Call.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Macron20190516T1420

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 2:20 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau on Canada's new digital plan and support on the 'Christchurch Call'

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says a new digital charter will dictate how the country will combat hate speech, misinformation and online electoral interference in Canada. He made the announcement at a technology conference in Paris. The move comes after signing on to the "Christchurch Call" - a pledge involving several world leaders and internet giants to stop the spread of hate online.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Paris-Internet20190516T1416

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 2:16 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau says he will work with allies to help detainees in China

Caption: In a news conference in Paris, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau spoke gravely but in vague terms about how Canada might respond to the arrests of two Canadians in China. Canadians Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor have been formally arrested after months in Chinese detention. Trudeau says Canada will work with allies to help the two men.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Paris-China20190516T1409

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris, Cda-China

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 2:09 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

COMING UP LATER (Subject to frequent change):

Coverage of the Newfoundland and Labrador election. (Late event, video will be available Friday morning)

AVAILABLE ON THE RAW CHANNEL:

Long: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau arrives at l'Élysée for the Christchurch Call meeting (May 15)

Long: B.C. Conservative MP Mark Warawa bids teary farewell to House of Commons (May 8)

SENT PREVIOUSLY:

Headline: Bank of Canada: Mortgage stress test has improved quality of lending but continued vigilance is important

Caption: The Bank of Canada released its annual Financial System Review on Thursday. Bank of Canada governor Stephen Poloz highlighted the effect of the mortgage stress test, as well as the current state of regional housing markets.

Filename: n_BoC-Poloz20190516T1300

Companion: BoC-FSR-Risks

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 1:00 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau meets with New Zealand prime minister in Paris

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met with New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern on Thursday at the Canadian Residence in Paris. The two spoke about New Zealand's plan for dealing with hate and extremism online in the wake of the Christchurch mosque attacks on March 19, 2019.

Filename: n_PMJT-Paris-Ardern20190516T0930

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 9:30 a.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Veterinarians brought dogs to Parliament Hill to campaign for medical cannabis for pets

Caption: Five dogs were a big hit on Parliament Hill as veterinarians lobbied for legal changes that would allow them to prescribe medical cannabis for animals. They stood outside the main doors of West Block, capturing the oohs and ahs of politicians and staff as they emerged after question period Wednesday.

Filename: n_Stampede-Food20190515T1945

Companion: Stampede-Food

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 7:45 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Calgary Stampede unveils its midway food list for 2019

Caption: This year's midway menu at the Calgary Stampede includes ice pops made from pickle juice, deep-fried chicken skin and octopus deep-fried or in a lollipop. The 10-day festival celebrating the cowboy life tries to outdo itself each year in its culinary offerings. Octopus will have a strong showing this summer, as will hearts - be they the deep-fried centres of artichokes or barbecued chicken hearts on a stick.

Filename: n_Stampede-Food20190515T1945

Companion: Stampede-Food

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 7:45 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Bains on tech giants, Christchurch Call

Caption: Canada's Minister of Innovation, Navdeep Bains, answered questions from reporters about being too soft on big tech companies such as Facebook. He was participating in a G7 meeting while Prime Minister Justin Trudeau was in Paris for the "Christchurch Call."

Filename: n_Bains-Tech-Data20190515T1745

Companion: Big-Data-Strategy

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 5:45 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Singh goes after Liberals over Phoenix fiasco

Caption: Public Services Minister Carla Qualtrough says the Liberals are keeping IBM accountable for failures with the Phoenix pay system. The company is getting more money to work on Phoenix even as the government works to replace what NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh describes as a mess.

Filename: n_Singh-Qualtrough-IBM20190515T1700

Companion: -

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 5:00 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Goodale calls RCMP interrogation video of Indigenous assault victim 'abhorrent'

Caption: Public Safety Minister Ralph Goodale is denouncing an aggressive 2012 interrogation of an under-age Indigenous sexual assault victim, following a story from and footage obtained by Aboriginal Peoples Television Network. Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer used the issue as his first question in question period after the details in the APTN story outraged MPs on Parliament Hill Wednesday.

Filename: n_Question-Period-RCMP-Goodale20190515T1651

Companion: -

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:51 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Tories ask Liberals to televise hearing on Mark Norman affair

Caption: Conservative defence critic James Bezan takes his turn in question period to ask the chair of the national defence committee to televise Thursday's meeting where MPs will debate an investigation of the Mark Norman affair. In response, government House leader Bardish Chagger says it's up to the committee.

Filename: n_Question-Period-Bezan-Norman20190515T1634

Companion: -

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:34 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: B.C. to hold money laundering public inquiry; final report due May 2021

Caption: Premier John Horgan has called a public inquiry into money laundering in British Columbia following three independent reviews that found money laundering in the province's real estate market and other sectors of the economy worth billions of dollars annually.

Filename: n_Money-Laundering-B.C.20190515T1600

Companion: Money-Laundering-BC

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:00 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Canadian Forest Service officials discuss this year's wildfire season

Caption: Canadian Forest Service have an update on the forecast for this year's fire season. According to Richard Carr, wildland fire analyst at Northern Forestry Centre, more western regions in Canada have an increase risk in fire severity. Ellen Whitman, fire research assistant at the Northern Forestry Centre, says that one of the main reasons for an increase of fires in Canada is due to climate change.

Filename: n_Wildfire-Forecast20190515T1540

Companion: Wildfire-Forecast

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 3:40 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Environment minister criticizes Conservative opponents on climate change

Caption: Environment Minister Catherine McKenna criticizes Opposition leader Andrew Scheer, Ontario Premier Doug Ford and Alberta Premier Jason Kenney over their climate change positions.

Filename: n_McKenna-Climate20190515T1317

Companion: McKenna-Climate-Motion

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 1:17 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Trudeau tours Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau took a tour of Paris's famed Notre Dame Cathedral, alongside Canada's French ambassador Isabelle Hudon, Notre-Dame de Paris' rector and archpriest, Patrick Chauvet, and France's Minister of Culture, Franck Riester. The iconic monument that was partially destroyed by fire in mid-April. Trudeau says it was an honour to be able to exhibit some of the solidarity Canadians feel toward their French cousins.

Filename: n_Trudeau-NotreDame20190515T1215

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 12:15 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Trudeau arrives in Paris

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has landed in Paris for a two-day visit that will include a summit later today about preventing violent extremist acts from being streamed online. As he stepped out of the plane, he was greeted by French ambassador Isabelle Hudon and chief of protocol Shannon Jinadasa.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Paris20190515T0820

Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 8:20 a.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Goodale says feds will defend against any legal action from Tori Stafford killer

Caption: Public Safety Minister Ralph Goodale says the federal government will defend itself against any legal action from Terri-Lynne McClintic, who was sentenced to life in prison in 2010 for her role in the first-degree murder of eight-year-old Tori Stafford. During question period Tuesday, Conservative MP Glen Motz asked about McClintic, whose transfer to an Indigenous healing lodge was reversed following a public outcry last year.

Filename: n_QP-Stafford-Goodale20190514T1701

Companion: McClintic-Prison

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 5:01 p.m. ET Tuesday, May 14

Headline: Trudeau faces off with Scheer, Singh for first time since Norman case dropped

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau faces off with Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer and NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh in the House of Commons for the first time since federal prosecutors dropped the breach-of-trust case against Vice-Admiral Mark Norman - and the issue dominated much of a boisterous question period.

Filename: n_QP-Scheer-Singh-Trudeau20190514T1545

Companion: Mark-Norman

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 3:45 p.m. ET Tuesday, May 14

Headline: Goodale avoids responding to Norman-case fallout

Caption: Federal cabinet is meeting in Ottawa today, and Chief of the Defence Staff Jonathan Vance and Jody Thomas, the deputy minister of defence, were both summoned to attend, a week after the criminal case against Vice-Admiral Mark Norman was stayed. Public Safety Minister Ralph Goodale says he will not comment on the quality of the RCMP investigation in the Norman case.

Filename: n_Mark-Norman-Cabinet20190514T1245

Companion: Mark-Norman

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 12:45 p.m. ET Tuesday, May 14

Headline: Dr. Ruth Westheimer on new doc 'Ask Dr. Ruth' and making her 'dent' in society

Caption: Sex therapist Dr. Ruth Westheimer says "the timing is right" for a new doc on her life, "Ask Dr. Ruth."

Filename: e_Film-Dr-Ruth20190514T0800

Companion: FILM-Ask-Dr-Ruth

Category: ENTERTAINMENT

Time Published: 8:00 a.m. ET Tuesday, May 14

Headline: Alex Trebek in Ottawa to open Royal Canadian Geographical Society's new HQ

Caption: 'Jeopardy!' host Alex Trebek visits Ottawa

NEW Filename: n_TV-Alex-Trebek-Ottawa20190514T0800

Companion: TV-Alex-Trebek-Ottawa

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 8:00 a.m. ET Tuesday, May 14

Headline: Jagmeet Singh says Liberals, Tories have same plan for climate change

Caption: NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh asked the Liberals to agree to declare a climate emergency and commit to stronger emissions targets. Liberal Health Minister Ginette Petipas-Taylor says the Liberals have a strong plan with over 50 measures to tackle climate change.

Filename: n_QP-Singh-Climate20190513T1634

Companion: Climate-Change-NDP

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:34 p.m. ET Monday, May 13

Headline: Museum in Neil Armstrong's hometown ready to celebrate 50th anniversary of first moon landing

Caption: This July marks 50 years since Neil Armstrong became the first man to walk on the moon. The Armstrong Air and Space Museum in his hometown of Wapakoneta, Ohio offers a unique insight into that event and the life of Neil Armstrong.

Filename: e_TRAVEL-Log-Neil-Armstrong20190513T0900

Companion: TRAVEL-Log-Neil-Armstrong

Category: ENTERTAINMENT

Time Published: 9:00 a.m. ET Monday, May 13

Headline: Kawhi Leonard buzzer-beater lifts Raptors to Game 7 win over Philadelphia 76ers

Caption: Kawhi Leonard scored a buzzer-beating jump shot to lift the Raptors 92-90 over the Philadelphia 76ers and into the Eastern Conference finals for the second time in franchise history. Leonard's shot bounced four times on the rim before falling, and he says the moment will be a highlight of his career. It was the first buzzer-beater in a Game 7 in NBA history. The Raptors face the Bucks in the finals, starting Wednesday in Milwaukee.

Filename: s_BKN-76ers-Raptors20190513T0900

Companion: BKN-76ers-Raptors

Category: SPORTS

Time Published: 9:00 a.m. ET Monday, May 13

Headline: Trudeau talks jobs, calls money laundering report alarming during stop in Alberta

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau came to Edmonton Friday, meeting with Mayor Don Iveson. He discussed new job numbers and a report out of British Columbia this week on the impact of money laundering on the economy, especially B.C. house prices. Trudeau also addressed the recent Alberta election and prospects for his Liberals in upcoming federal campaign.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Jobs-Alberta20190510T1631

Companion: Money-Laundering-BC, StatCan-Jobs

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 4:31 p.m. ET Friday, May 10

Headline: Hockey Hall of Famer Red Kelly laid to rest

Caption: A funeral for hockey great Red Kelly was held on Friday in Toronto. Kelly, who starred for the Detroit Red Wings and Toronto Maple Leafs, has died at age 91.

Filename: s_HKN-Red-Kelly-Funeral20190510T1427

Companion: HKN-Red-Kelly-Funeral

Category: SPORTS

Time Published: 2:27 p.m. ET Friday, May 10

Headline: Veterans Affairs taken to task for online Second World War video featuring German soldiers

Caption: Veterans Affairs Minister Lawrence MacAulay apologizes for a mistake where footage of German troops, not Canadian soldiers, was used in an online video to mark 74 years since the end of fighting in Europe during the Second World War. Under questioning in the House of Commons, MacAulay says he has asked for a review and doesn't want the error to detract from the message to ensure the atrocities of that war never happen again. Later, former Conservative defence minister Rob Nicholson can be seen standing and applauding MacAulay's comments.

Filename: n_War-German-Video20190510T1213

Companion: -

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 12:13 p.m. ET Friday, May 10

Headline: Trudeau calls on all political leaders to denounce hate and Islamophobia

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau attended a community Iftar dinner Thursday and praised Canada's Pakistani community. He denounced all forms of Islamophobia and says that all political leaders must call it out when they see it.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Islamophobia20190510T1000

Companion: -

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 10:00 a.m. ET Friday, May 10

Headline: Trudeau appearance at Liberal event interrupted by Grassy Narrows protester

Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's armchair discussion with Liberal MP Adam Vaughan at an event with party supporters in Toronto was interrupted by a Grassy Narrows protester.

Filename: n_Trudeau-Protester20190510T0845

Companion: Grassy-Narrows

Category: NEWS

Time Published: 8:45 p.m. ET Friday, May 10

Latest video from the Canadian Press:

Headline: Toronto-bred star Mena Massoud talks "Aladdin" Caption: Mena Massoud, star of the new live-action "Aladdin" movie, discussed his relationship with the original film, why he believes in diverse casting, and his experience shooting the remake. Filename: e_Mena-Massoud-Aladdin20190523T1715 Companion: FILM-Aladdin-Massoud Category: ENTERTAINMENT Time Published: 5:15 p.m. ET Thursday, May 23

Headline: Trudeau exonerates Poundmaker Caption: More than 130 years after he was charged and convicted of felony-treason, Chief Poundmaker is exonerated of the unjust charge by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. Trudeau visited Poundmaker Cree Nation to deliver his statement of exoneration in front of many of First Nations residents and leaders who says Poundmaker was a peacekeeper, not a rebel. Filename: n_Poundmaker-Exonerated-Sask20190523T1645 Companion: Trudeau-Poundmaker-Exoneration Category: NEWS Time Published: 4:45 p.m. ET Thursday, May 23

Headline: Money Monitor: Donor-advised funds Caption: Millions of Canadians dig into their wallets and donate to charities every year, but if you want to build a lasting charitable legacy, experts say a donor-advised fund might be for you. Bibi Patel, vice-president at the Ottawa Community Foundation, says a donor-advised fund is like having your own private foundation, but without the administrative headaches Filename: b_Money-Monitor20190523T1000 Companion: Money-Monitor Category: BUSINESS Time Published: 10:00 a.m. ET Thursday, May 23

Headline: Trudeau touts economic record at Liberal fundraiser in Vancouver Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau takes aim at Conservative 'trickle down economics,' touts Liberal investment in middle class at pricey fundraiser in Vancouver. Filename: n_Trudeau-BC-Fundraiser20190523T0830 Companion: Trudeau-BC-Fundraiser Category: NEWS Time Published: 8:30 a.m. ET Thursday, May 23

Headline: Alberta launches spring sitting with bill to kill provincial carbon tax Caption: Premier Jason Kenney began the spring sitting with his new United Conservative government by introducing a bill to kill the provincial carbon tax by May 30th. Filename: n_Kenney-Notley-Carbon20190522T1922 Companion: Kenney-Notley-Carbon Category: NEWS Time Published: 7:22 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 22

Headline: Protester interrupts Trudeau in Vancouver Caption: Anti-pipeline protester Will George of the Tsleil-Waututh Nation interrupts Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at a Liberal fundraiser in Vancouver. Dozens of anti-pipeline protesters gathered outside the event. Filename: n_Protest-Trudeau-Pipeline20190522T1733 Companion: Protest-Trudeau-Pipeline Category: NEWS Time Published: 5:33 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 22

Headline: Ontario Premier Doug Ford meets with New Brunswick Premier Blaine Higgs at Queen's Park Caption: Ontario Premier Doug Ford meet with his New Brunswick counterpart today to discuss a number of issues, including their shared opposition to the federal carbon tax. Ford and Blaine Higgs have both been vocal in their opposition to the tax, which the federal government imposed earlier this year on provinces that didn't have their own price on carbon. Filename: n_Ford-Higgs-Toronto20190522T1645 Companion: Ont-Ford-Higgs Category: NEWS Time Published: 4:45 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 22

Headline: Trudeau announces new Coast Guard fleet Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announces a "full renewal" of the Canadian Coast Guard fleet. Filename: n_Coast-Guard-Ships20190522T1400 Companion: Coast-Guard-Ships Category: NEWS Time Published: 2:00 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 22

Headline: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in Kamloops Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau was in Kamloops Tuesday evening for the nomination meeting of Terry Lake, a former B.C. health minister, in the riding of Kamloops-Thompson-Cariboo. Filename: n_Trudeau-Kamloops20190522T0830 Companion: Trudeau-Kamloops Category: NEWS Time Published: 8:30 a.m. ET Wednesday, May 22

Upcoming:

Winnipeg. RCMP's investigation of child sexual and physical abuse involving multiple victims in Garden Hill First Nation. (expected next) Meadow Lakes, Saskatchewan. Prime Minister meets with First Nations leaders. Calgary. Sports Hall of Fame announces 2019 inductees.

SENT PREVIOUSLY:

Headline: Quebec zoo owner charged with animal cruelty Caption: Animal welfare officials are seizing over 100 animals from a small zoo in Quebec after an investigation found alleged abuse and neglect. The Montreal SPCA says the owner is facing one count each of criminal animal neglect and criminal animal cruelty, and say it's the first time in Canada that a zoo owner has faced such charges. Filename: n_Zoo-Cruelty-Quebec20190521T1750 Companion: CRIME-Exotic-Animal-Seizure Category: NEWS Time Published: 5:50 p.m. ET Tuesday, May 21

Headline: No chance at parole for 50 years for Calgary double killer Caption: Double murderer Edward Downey has been sentenced to life in prison with no chance of parole for 50 years. He was convicted of two counts of first-degree murder in the 2016 deaths of Sara Baillie, 34, and her five-year-old daughter Taliyah Marsman. Filename: n_Calgary-Murder-Sentencing20190521T1650 Companion: CRIME-Mother-Daughter-Dead Category: NEWS Time Published: 4:50 p.m. ET Tuesday, May 21 Headline: Premier Ford promises funding to help large cities and school boards find savings Caption: Premier Doug Ford says the province is willing to pay for large municipalities and school boards to review their budgets in an effort to find savings. Filename: n_Ont-Municipal-Funding20190521T1600 Companion: Ont-Municipal-Funding Category: NEWS Time Published: 4:00 p.m. ET Tuesday, May 21

Headline: Innovation Minister Navdeep Bains introduces digital charter Caption: Innovation Minister Navdeep Bains introduced a digital charter aimed at protecting privacy and personal control of data. Speaking at an Empire Club of Canada event in Toronto, Bains says the government will review the Privacy Act and take other measures to build trust in a digital world. Filename: n_Bains-Digital-Privacy20190521T1405 Companion: Bains-Digital-Charter Category: NEWS Time Published: 2:05 p.m. ET Tuesday, May 21

Headline: Retaliation key to ending trade dispute: PM Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says Canada's retaliatory tariffs on American goods were key to restoring free access to the U.S. market for Canadian steel and aluminum. Trudeau paid a visit Tuesday to Aluminerie Alouette, an aluminum plant in Sept-Iles, Que., where he was joined by CEO Patrice L'Huillier in celebrating last week's agreement to end punitive U.S. duties on Canadian metal exports. The U.S. imposed import taxes of 25 per cent on Canadian steel and 10 per cent on aluminum a year ago as a pressure tactic when negotiations on a new North American free-trade agreement got difficult. Filename: n_Trudeau-US-Tariffs20190521T1245 Companion: Trudeau-Tariffs Category: NEWS Time Published: 12:45 p.m. ET Tuesday, May 21

Headline: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau speaks at technology conference in Toronto Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau told hundreds of attendees at a conference in Toronto on Monday that Canada's thriving technology sector is a result of the country's openness to immigrants and he hopes Canadians will continue to view immigration positively. Filename: n_Trudeau-TechConference20190521T0840 Companion: Trudeau-Immigration-Tech Category: NEWS Time Published: 08:40 a.m. ET Tuesday, May 21

Headline: B.C. Lions kick off training camp Caption: A new-look B.C. Lions squad is hitting the field for training camp following a flurry of roster moves over the off-season. Filename: s_CFL-BC-Lions20190520T1845 Companion: CFL-BC-Lions Category: SPORTS Time Published: 6:45 p.m. ET Monday, May 20

Headline: Canada, U.S. tariff dispute over: Trudeau Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced Friday that the U.S. has agreed to lift its punitive tariffs on steel and aluminum, putting an end to a year-long dispute. Filename: n_Trudeau-Tariffs-Hamilton20190517T1710 Companion: Trudeau-Tariffs Category: NEWS Time Published: 5:10 p.m. ET Friday, May 17

Headline: RCMP video should shock Canadians: Sinclair Caption: Former Truth and Reconciliation commissioner Murray Sinclair says a video of a Mountie interrogating a young Indigenous woman disclosing sexual abuse in B.C. foster care brings home in a "visceral way" a reality that Canadians should be shocked by and one that they need to see. The 2012 video was released publicly by APTN this week as a result of a court proceeding and has prompted political reaction. Sinclair tells The Canadian Press in an interview that the video should cause Canadians to be more supportive of those who say police officers require more oversight. Filename: n_RCMP-Sinclair20190517T1625 Companion: RCMP-Sinclair Category: NEWS Time Published: 4:25 p.m. ET Friday, May 17

Headline: Mark Norman affair needs public inquiry, Scheer says Caption: Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer says Canada needs a public inquiry into the case of Vice-Admiral Mark Norman. On Parliament Hill Friday, Scheer says a full investigation is justified to examine how the military's former second-in-command came to be charged with over alleged leaks of cabinet secrets about a shipbuilding contract. The case against Norman collapsed last week after Crown prosecutors got new information from the defence that convinced them they stood no reasonable chance of landing a conviction. Filename: n_Scheer-Mark-Norman20190517T1549 Companion: Mark-Norman Category: NEWS Time Published: 3:49 p.m. ET Friday, May 17

Headline: Scheer speaks as long-awaited end to Canada's tariff standoff with U.S. finally at hand Caption: Canada's year-long standoff with the Trump administration over punitive U.S. steel and aluminum tariffs is finally over, sources say, removing a key hurdle in efforts to ratify the new North American trade pact. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau was to make an unscheduled, last-minute trip to Hamilton, Canada's steel-manufacturing capital, to confirm the breakthrough at an event at steel giant Stelco. Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer spoke about the tariffs issue in Ottawa prior to Trudeau's statement. Filename: n_Scheer-Cda-US-Tariffs20190517T1400 Companion: Cda-US-Tariffs Category: NEWS Time Published: 2:00 p.m. ET Friday, May 17

Headline: Conservatives prod Liberals over report Trudeau pushed Norman leak Caption: The Mark Norman affair dominated question period Friday in the House of Commons, fueled by a report in the Globe and Mail newspaper that Prime Minister Justin Trudeau pushed for an investigation over the leak of cabinet secrets regarding a $700 million shipbuilding contract. Filename: n_Norman-Bezan-Chagger20190517T1303 Companion: Mark-Norman Category: NEWS Time Published: 1:03 p.m. ET Friday, May 17

Headline: Dan Aykroyd on reviving 'Ghostbusters' for a new generation Caption: Dan Aykroyd says he "proudly" counts 2016's female-centric "Ghostbusters" as part of the pantheon: "I like my girl Ghostbusters." He discusses the 1984 original ghost-comedy, director Paul Feig's revival and the new "Ghostbusters" movie which Aykroyd will be producing. Filename: e_Aykroyd-Ghostbusters20190517T0900 Companion: FILM-Aykroyd-Ghostbusters Category: ENTERTAINMENT Time Published: 9:00 a.m. ET Friday, May 17

Headline: N.L. party leaders react to Liberal minority win Caption: Newfoundland and Labrador elected a rare minority government Thursday night. Dwight Ball's Liberals squeaked by with a diminished seat count while Progressive Conservative Leader Ches Crosbie said he hopes to topple the government within a year. Filename: n_NL-Election20190517T0815 Companion: NL-Elxn Category: NEWS Time Published: 8:15 a.m. ET Friday, May 17

Headline: Conservative MP says Trudeau acting like a 'coward' on China detentions Caption: Conservative House leader Candice Bergen draws the ire of Speaker Geoff Regan after she says Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is acting like a coward in dealing with China. Declining relations between the two countries slid lower Thursday after Canadians Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor were formally arrested after months in Chinese detention. Filename: n_Bergen-Cda-China20190516T1648 Companion: Cda-China Category: NEWS Time Published: 4:48 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Liberals say they want Senate to revive tanker ban bill Caption: Terry Beech, Transport Minister Marc Garneau's parliamentary secretary, says the government hopes the Senate continues debate on a bill that would ban oil tankers along parts of the B.C. coast. In response to a Conservative question, Beech also says the government will consider amendments reflecting the spirit of the legislation. Filename: n_Environment-Assessment-Bill20190516T1615 Companion: Environment-Assessment-Bill Category: NEWS Time Published: 4:15 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Scheer promises energy corridor; Morneau says Scheer has 'no credible' economic plan Caption: Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer says Canada needs a coast-to-coast energy corridor where it would be easy to build pipelines and power lines. In a speech laying out his economic vision before the next election, the opposition leader says having one dedicated route would make it easier to approve major new energy projects. Finance Minister Bill Morneau responded to Scheer's plan, saying the pipeline plan is a "risky" approach. Filename: n_Scheer-Economics-Morneau20190516T1602 Companion: Scheer-Economics Category: NEWS Time Published: 4:02 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau talks at VivaTech in Paris, meets with startups Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says he is confident a new digital charter being launched by Canada will make the internet a safer place. Speaking at the VivaTech conference in Paris today, Trudeau says the framework will dictate how the country will combat hate speech, misinformation and online electoral interference in Canada. After the announcement, Trudeau met with representatives from Canadian startups and tech companies. Filename: n_Trudeau-VivaTech-Paris20190516T1525 Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris Category: NEWS Time Published: 3:25 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau meets with Macron at l'Élysée Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met with French president Emmanuel Macron at l'Élysée in Paris. Trudeau says the two leaders talked about their common goal of better regulating the web against hateful speech in the wake of the Christchurch Call. Filename: n_Trudeau-Macron20190516T1420 Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris Category: NEWS Time Published: 2:20 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau on Canada's new digital plan and support on the 'Christchurch Call' Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says a new digital charter will dictate how the country will combat hate speech, misinformation and online electoral interference in Canada. He made the announcement at a technology conference in Paris. The move comes after signing on to the "Christchurch Call" - a pledge involving several world leaders and internet giants to stop the spread of hate online. Filename: n_Trudeau-Paris-Internet20190516T1416 Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris Category: NEWS Time Published: 2:16 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau says he will work with allies to help detainees in China Caption: In a news conference in Paris, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau spoke gravely but in vague terms about how Canada might respond to the arrests of two Canadians in China. Canadians Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor have been formally arrested after months in Chinese detention. Trudeau says Canada will work with allies to help the two men. Filename: n_Trudeau-Paris-China20190516T1409 Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris, Cda-China Category: NEWS Time Published: 2:09 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Bank of Canada: Mortgage stress test has improved quality of lending but continued vigilance is important Caption: The Bank of Canada released its annual Financial System Review on Thursday. Bank of Canada governor Stephen Poloz highlighted the effect of the mortgage stress test, as well as the current state of regional housing markets. Filename: n_BoC-Poloz20190516T1300 Companion: BoC-FSR-Risks Category: NEWS Time Published: 1:00 p.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Trudeau meets with New Zealand prime minister in Paris Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met with New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern on Thursday at the Canadian Residence in Paris. The two spoke about New Zealand's plan for dealing with hate and extremism online in the wake of the Christchurch mosque attacks on March 19, 2019. Filename: n_PMJT-Paris-Ardern20190516T0930 Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris Category: NEWS Time Published: 9:30 a.m. ET Thursday, May 16

Headline: Veterinarians brought dogs to Parliament Hill to campaign for medical cannabis for pets Caption: Five dogs were a big hit on Parliament Hill as veterinarians lobbied for legal changes that would allow them to prescribe medical cannabis for animals. They stood outside the main doors of West Block, capturing the oohs and ahs of politicians and staff as they emerged after question period Wednesday. Filename: n_Stampede-Food20190515T1945 Companion: Stampede-Food Category: NEWS Time Published: 7:45 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Calgary Stampede unveils its midway food list for 2019 Caption: This year's midway menu at the Calgary Stampede includes ice pops made from pickle juice, deep-fried chicken skin and octopus deep-fried or in a lollipop. The 10-day festival celebrating the cowboy life tries to outdo itself each year in its culinary offerings. Octopus will have a strong showing this summer, as will hearts - be they the deep-fried centres of artichokes or barbecued chicken hearts on a stick. Filename: n_Stampede-Food20190515T1945 Companion: Stampede-Food Category: NEWS Time Published: 7:45 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Bains on tech giants, Christchurch Call Caption: Canada's Minister of Innovation, Navdeep Bains, answered questions from reporters about being too soft on big tech companies such as Facebook. He was participating in a G7 meeting while Prime Minister Justin Trudeau was in Paris for the "Christchurch Call." Filename: n_Bains-Tech-Data20190515T1745 Companion: Big-Data-Strategy Category: NEWS Time Published: 5:45 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Singh goes after Liberals over Phoenix fiasco Caption: Public Services Minister Carla Qualtrough says the Liberals are keeping IBM accountable for failures with the Phoenix pay system. The company is getting more money to work on Phoenix even as the government works to replace what NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh describes as a mess. Filename: n_Singh-Qualtrough-IBM20190515T1700 Companion: - Category: NEWS Time Published: 5:00 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Goodale calls RCMP interrogation video of Indigenous assault victim 'abhorrent' Caption: Public Safety Minister Ralph Goodale is denouncing an aggressive 2012 interrogation of an under-age Indigenous sexual assault victim, following a story from and footage obtained by Aboriginal Peoples Television Network. Conservative Leader Andrew Scheer used the issue as his first question in question period after the details in the APTN story outraged MPs on Parliament Hill Wednesday. Filename: n_Question-Period-RCMP-Goodale20190515T1651 Companion: - Category: NEWS Time Published: 4:51 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Tories ask Liberals to televise hearing on Mark Norman affair Caption: Conservative defence critic James Bezan takes his turn in question period to ask the chair of the national defence committee to televise Thursday's meeting where MPs will debate an investigation of the Mark Norman affair. In response, government House leader Bardish Chagger says it's up to the committee. Filename: n_Question-Period-Bezan-Norman20190515T1634 Companion: - Category: NEWS Time Published: 4:34 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: B.C. to hold money laundering public inquiry; final report due May 2021 Caption: Premier John Horgan has called a public inquiry into money laundering in British Columbia following three independent reviews that found money laundering in the province's real estate market and other sectors of the economy worth billions of dollars annually. Filename: n_Money-Laundering-B.C.20190515T1600 Companion: Money-Laundering-BC Category: NEWS Time Published: 4:00 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Canadian Forest Service officials discuss this year's wildfire season Caption: Canadian Forest Service have an update on the forecast for this year's fire season. According to Richard Carr, wildland fire analyst at Northern Forestry Centre, more western regions in Canada have an increase risk in fire severity. Ellen Whitman, fire research assistant at the Northern Forestry Centre, says that one of the main reasons for an increase of fires in Canada is due to climate change. Filename: n_Wildfire-Forecast20190515T1540 Companion: Wildfire-Forecast Category: NEWS Time Published: 3:40 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Environment minister criticizes Conservative opponents on climate change Caption: Environment Minister Catherine McKenna criticizes Opposition leader Andrew Scheer, Ontario Premier Doug Ford and Alberta Premier Jason Kenney over their climate change positions. Filename: n_McKenna-Climate20190515T1317 Companion: McKenna-Climate-Motion Category: NEWS Time Published: 1:17 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Trudeau tours Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau took a tour of Paris's famed Notre Dame Cathedral, alongside Canada's French ambassador Isabelle Hudon, Notre-Dame de Paris' rector and archpriest, Patrick Chauvet, and France's Minister of Culture, Franck Riester. The iconic monument that was partially destroyed by fire in mid-April. Trudeau says it was an honour to be able to exhibit some of the solidarity Canadians feel toward their French cousins. Filename: n_Trudeau-NotreDame20190515T1215 Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris Category: NEWS Time Published: 12:15 p.m. ET Wednesday, May 15

Headline: Trudeau arrives in Paris Caption: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has landed in Paris for a two-day visit that will include a summit later today about preventing violent extremist acts from being streamed online. As he stepped out of the plane, he was greeted by French ambassador Isabelle Hudon and chief of protocol Shannon Jinadasa. Filename: n_Trudeau-Paris20190515T0820 Companion: Cda-Trudeau-Paris Category: NEWS Time Published: 8:20 a.m. ET Wednesday, May 15
